The disproportionate number of black women voluntarily enlisting in the military in the 1980s as well as their political invisibility needs to be explained in order to make sense of how the current military recruitment strategies exploit women's frustrations and hopes. Black women-especially young black women-suffer some of the highest unemployment and underemployment rates in the American labour force. They, even more than white women, live in conditions which offer few options.

She goes on to explain that that is one of the pressures which lead them to enter the armed forces. At page 132 the same point is made. I do not think I have time to quote from that. We must not close our eyes to the fact that many women, if combat related duties were open to them, would find themselves in that situation not from real choice but because that particular militarisation of their lives would be the only option open to them. In a review of that book in the Age on Friday, 7 October, Dorothy Green, a well-known writer on these matters, said concerning the military:
. . . its authority is sustained by powerful myths, the most deeply embedded of which is the belief that the ultimate test of manliness is combat.
The central issue-
that is, to this whole question of women serving-
is the militarisation of women.
. . . the book should be read by women, if only to alert them to the dangers of regarding greater access to careers in the armed forces as a step towards women' s liberation.
In regard to these military myths, it goes on to say:
In breaking free from them-
that is the military myths-
women have a tremendous opportunity to say to men: ''We have had enough. If you want to go on fighting count us out.''

It is in that general framework that I support the Government's decision at the moment not to make it unlawful to discriminate against women by not permitting them to serve in combat zones. I repeat that what should constitute service in combat zones should be as narrowly defined as possible so that women do get as many opportunities as possible to find employment, if they so choose, within the armed military forces and to get that training, apprenticeship skills, or whatever it might be. Because the definition of what shall constitute combat duties will come back to this chamber, because it will be made by regulation, we will have an opportunity to disallow any too-wide definition of the scope of what should constitute combat zones. I for one will certainly be trying to confine the interpretation as narrowly as possible. I believe that is what we ought to do in this chamber.

The other matter of some concern which is put by many people is that the Bill could convert a woman's decision to have an abortion into a right to demand that abortion. I have never thought that this Bill could be strained to bear an interpretation which would permit such a manipulation of its terms to achieve that end, an end which was never intended by those who promoted and drafted this Bill. I believe that no further clause was strictly needed to make that clear, but in deference to a certain amount of, at times, hysterical public pressure a clause has been drafted which I believe more than adequately achieves that end. The clause dealing with goods, services and facilities states:
Nothing in the section applies to or in respect of the provision of services the nature of which is such that they can only be provided to members of one sex .

I think that makes it very clear that, in relation to the provision of medical services which are specific to the persons of one sex, the Bill has no application whatsoever. That would include not only an abortion but also sterilisation procedures. The refusal of such a service cannot form the basis of a complaint under the Act. Other laws of States or Territories deal with such matters.

Of course, the new clause is declaratory and utterly in line with the general policy of the Bill, which is concerned with discriminatory practices and is not concerned to confer rights peculiar to the one sex. That would be quite alien to the Bill. I have had conversations with many of those who originally were aroused to have fears and misgivings about this proposal. I think it would be fair to say that most of the reasonable ones amongst them have been satisfied. Certainly Mrs Tighe, of the Right To Life Association, who is a terrier around these corridors, as honourable senators will know, has indicated to me that she and her legal advisers are satisfied that this declaratory clause sets out the true position under the Bill. I only regret that some genuine and very sincere people have had their concerns about abortion in Australian society, and indeed its impact on the women who are subject to them, manipulated and fanned by those who are seeking their own political aggrandisement. For that reason I think I can assert that this clause, which may be open to some modification at the Committee stage, is designed to and does achieve that declaration of what the Bill is all about.

The Bill has nothing to do with conferring any right to abortion or sterilisation. If people were really concerned about how some work practices, for example, can effect women who are pregnant, perhaps they ought to have taken a more positive line; their voices would have been so much more easily listened to. In relation to that matter, for example, one can find some very interesting provisions in the United States of America. For example, the American Federation of Labor/ Congress of Industrial Organizations-that is the equivalent of the Australian Council of Trade Unions-provides the following recommendation:

When a woman is pregnant the health hazards to which she is exposed are a threat to her child as well as to herself. Toxic substances that enter her bloodstream are transmitted to the foetus . . . She must avoid even small exposures to toxic substances . . . And, most importantly, she must have a clause in her contract--
her contract of work-

that protects her right to transfer to a safer part of the plant without loss of pay or seniority for the duration of the pregnancy . . . The Contract should also require the labelling of substances known to be . . . abortifacients. No woman should ever have to choose between her job security and her baby's health.

Perhaps if we had heard something more positive from some of the more hysterical quarters along those lines, as I say, we would have found dealing with them a much better experience than it was. In any case, I assert that their fears are allayed.

Finally, as to the argument that educational institutions ought not be required to tolerate on their premises or have in their midst those whose activities or even gender are not in accordance with the ethos or values which the institution is attempting to instil in its pupils, I believe that there were very real difficulties in assenting to this argument. After all, the Bill is part of a recognition that we, as elected representatives of the people, wish to eliminate practices in our society which deny fulfilment in employment or educational opportunities to any person within Australia on the grounds of their sex, marital status or pregnancy. It is hard to see why enclaves of resistence to this concept should be tolerated, particularly when these institutions are forming the outlook and values of the coming generations of adult Australians who will be responsible for the upbringing of their children, we hope in a society not dominated or determined by expectations of men and women which may limit their chances of reaching human fulfilment. However, certain concessions, once again, have been made. I support the Government insofar as those concessions have been made. Very broadly speaking, in relation to educational institutions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the permanency of the exemptions?

—I do if I can explain how I understand the exemptions. In this sense, what is provided in relation to educational institutions, is that they can discriminate on the grounds of marital status, pregnancy or sex, in relation to a particular teacher, say, where the discrimination is in accordance with the doctrines of the religion or creed and the discrimination occurs in good faith. In other words, it is not enough for the school to say: 'Extra-marital pregnancy or a de facto marriage is outside the scope of sexual relations as approved by our particular ethical code or religious tenets or creed'. That would not be enough to render the sacking of the teacher lawful. What has to be shown is that the discrimination itself on those grounds is required by the tenets of the religion or creed; that is, the conduct itself is not enough to trigger the making lawful of what would otherwise be discriminatory practices. The discrimination itself has to flow from the ethos, the creed, the values, of that particular educational institution.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at it in that light, the whole bundle of values which say a Christian school is trying to instil in its pupils has to lead to the conclusion that discrimination leading to a deprivation of livelihood of the teacher is required . It would not be enough to say that an extra-marital pregnancy or a de facto relationship is against the tenets of the religion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Homosexuality could be a disqualification.

—That has nothing to do with this Bill. The Bill does not deal with sexual preference. In other words, one has to take into account that whole bundle of values of the religion, creed or, as Senator Durack pointed out, humanist values which might be the ethos behind the founding and the conduct of the school. When we do that, we have to take into account matters such as tolerance and some sort of compassion towards those engaging in that sort of activity, even if the activity itself is not condoned. I say that if indeed those educational institutions of learning are trying to transform and enhance the lives of their pupils by instilling certain values in them, they should see this as an opportunity to expose their pupils to that wider bundle of values, including compassion and tolerance, and there should not be merely an automatic reaction to the transgressing of some sexual ethic.
—Tolerance is not a great virtue in some schools.

—I believe that Senator Ryan received certain undertakings, for example, from the Victorian Catholic Education Commission that the pregnancy of a school teacher would not be a cause for dismissal and, in fact, the normal practice was to grant leave of absence. That, of course, is the humane and tolerant thing to do. However, to summarise on that point, it is simply not good enough to show some transgression of a moral law within the religion or creed concerned. Discrimination must also be demanded by the whole bundle of beliefs, the whole body and ethos and tenets of the religion. That ought to be harder to establish than may have been thought.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Bill. It marks a most important point in our maturing as a society. It fulfils in a commendable way our international undertakings. It is jurisprudentially sound in that it makes unlawful only certain defined practices . It does not fasten on to frames of mind or attitudes. It does fasten on to, and render unlawful, activities which are either clearly discriminatory or of the nature of sexual harassment. It largely depends on conciliation and orders to redress wrongs suffered rather than the creation of criminal offences. In these ways I believe that in ridding ourselves of discriminatory practices and activities we will create a situation in which frames of mind and expectations will change such that we all, men and women in Australia, will live more humanly fulfilling lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise today and support what I believe is a long overdue and very necessary piece of legislation. Indeed, if I have any complaints at all about this Bill they are along the lines that it does not go far enough. The aim of this Bill is to promote recognition and acceptance within the community of the principle of the equality of men and women. Indeed, I hope it goes beyond that. I hope that it also promotes an acceptance within the community of the practice of equality of men and women.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people have written to me alleging that they are Christians. They have argued very vehemently that the Bible in fact says that men and women are not equal, that women should remain in submission to and be disciplined by men and should in no way compete with a man. I would refer them only to St Paul's epistle to the Galatians. St Paul, who was probably history's greatest misogynist, refers-I think in verses 26 to 29, although this depends on one's version of the Bible-to the need for men and women to be treated as equals under the law. The Government, in an attempt to achieve these very worthwhile goals, has introduced legislation which aims to eliminate as far as possible-of course, as I think Senator Durack pointed out, we are not going to rid ourselves totally of the biases of some of the bigots in society-discrimination against persons on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the areas of work, accommodation, education, the provision of goods, facilities and services, the disposal of land, the activities of clubs and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs.

Inevitably, there has been an outcry as well as a lot of applause following the introduction of this Bill. Some of the outcry has consisted of deliberate emotional fear-raising and misrepresentation. Some of it has been genuine but misguided concern. I would like at this point to remind honourable senators and listeners to the debate that very similar emotional arguments were raised over three other legal movements that have taken place in the last 100 years in relation to establishing something like equal opportunities for women.

The first of those related to the Married Womens Property Act in 1883 which, of course, was met with ferocious opposition from a lot of men. Until 1883 a women who married and brought into her marriage property was forced to hand over all the property to her husband. She had neither ownership nor oversight of it. If she earned money, the money became his and, in the case of a divorce, he retained the property she had brought with her and anything she had earned between the marriage and the divorce. When the British Parliament acted to end this appalling situation, there were outcries of how it would break up marriages , bring on nervous breakdowns-presumably in the male; it was never made particularly clear who was to suffer the nervous breakdown-and, for some obscure reason, cause infertility, presumably as a result of the breakdown of the marriage.

The second major struggle that was undertaken in Britain and in other Western countries was one to allow women access to equal education, which was at that stage the norm for men and boys. Some medical practitioners, outraged at the thought of this, protested that if women had access to education which included a study of the sciences, maths and so on-subjects other than just needlework and literature-it would inhibit lactation, cause atrophy of the uterus, produce infertility and bring on nervous breakdowns. To the best of my knowledge, that has not happened-I am sure that the young ladies up in the gallery could indicate whether at the end of a maths lesson or a science lesson they have ever felt particularly infertile or likely to have a nervous breakdown. Their teachers may well have felt likely to have such a breakdown, but I am not sure the girls themselves have.

The next major move for equality for women in the Western world related to the right to vote and the right to be elected to parliament. Again, it was argued that women would not want it and that the time was not right. That argument is always a good one. It was argued that in any case women did not understand politics and that such a move would cause dissension in the home and break up marriages, presumably on the grounds that a women might dare not only to vote differently from her husband, but also to indicate to him, somewhat unwisely, that she was planning to vote differently from him.

It seems to me that the sometimes hysterical complaints about this piece of legislation relate to equally improbable events, although so far I have not heard that this Sex Discrimination Bill will inhibit lactation or cause infertility. I have, however, heard that it will break up marriages for the reason, presumably, that it will end the domination in some cases of the husband over the wife. That is something, apparently, that he will not be able to handle . The Institute of Public Affairs in New South Wales has put out a multi-page pamphlet in which it expresses, through Dr Clair Isbister, some of its concerns about the legislation. For instance, it states:
The basic philosophy of this Bill is to remove as far as possible all differences between men and women-

I am not quite sure what the Institute means by 'all differences'. I am not sure whether it is referring to physical differences or just to psychological ones, or whether it is talking about education and employment differences. I cannot see how it can possibly end all differences between men and women. Despite the Freudian remarks about assertive women, that they suffer only from penis envy, I have yet to meet a woman who suffers from that, or who has any particular desire to acquire that section of the male anatomy. The document says that the Bill intends to 'remove the stereotype of man being the primary bread-winner and woman the primary care-giver for children and homemaker'. It does not, though, remove the right of a man to be the primary bread-winner and a woman the primary care-giver if that is what they choose. It does, however, allow the situation in which the woman is not forced to be the caregiver and the man to be the breadwinner if they choose, and in that regard it is something devoutly to be wished. The pamphlet then goes on to say:
The individual replaces the family as the basic unit of society and, to ensure unisex equality-
whatever that is-
it removes pregnancy as any disadvantage to employment, quite regardless of the welfare of the child.

All I can say is that I managed successfully, with no damage either to myself or my two offspring, to carry my two daughters through almost the full stages of my pregnancy while I was working. I was fortunate enough to be employed in a private institution which allowed me to take the babies with me when I went back to work. Again, no-one, not I, they or the people I was teaching at the time, suffered in any way at all that I am aware of. Certainly my children are a darned sight better balanced than the children I know of some families in which the mother has stayed at home and taken on the traditional role of primary caregiver and the husband has gone out and done his breadwinning bit. The document continues:

It also requires the provision of extensive child minding from a very early age , usually at government expense to allow women in the work force to further their own desires regardless of the family needs.

Providing the children are being well looked after and fed, as they usually are in well organised child care centres, and providing everybody at home eats well, I can see no particular harm in that. Of course, if her husband does not like it he can always stay home and look after the children. There should not be any imposition on making it only the woman's role to stay at home. It goes on to say :
Family men and women are protesting that this Bill favours women in the work force and discourages women from taking time off paid employment to rear their children.

If it does, it is only because of a long-standing tradition in Australia, and in other countries as well, which gives no credit at all for the talents required to run a home and to bring up children. If the accounting, budgeting and personnel management skills and talents that a woman requires on the home front were taken into account when she went back to get a job then perhaps she would not feel discouraged from taking time off paid employment to rear their children . Finally, the document asserts:

Many consider that paid maternity leave in the public service has been abused. It disorganises schools, hospitals and many employers find it difficult to make allowances for the problems of employing pregnant women.

I wonder why this is any different from the problems for those organisations when they employ men who are entitled to, and about to take, paid long service leave or sabbatical leave. They are both usually confined to men and yet schools , hospitals and many employers do not seem to find it difficult to make allowances for the problems raised by sometimes six months paid long service leave or a twelve-month sabbatical.

This Bill in effect is not going to do a lot of the things that some people have asserted that it will do. It will not put us in the hands of communist countries. It will not make Australia the same as those communist countries which have ratified the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. I point out that although, as is frequently stated, the United States of America and Great Britain have not ratified this Convention, both have signed it, indicating that they intend to ratify it. Canada has ratified the Convention. To the best of my knowledge, there has been no indication of unisexism rearing its ugly head in Canada. It is said that sex stereotypes in books, advertising and so on will be banned. All I can say to that is that rather than complaining about it I am cheering it on. I see no reason at all why children should be brought up from the cradle to believe that women are less intelligent, less capable and less effective members of society than men, with a narrower range of roles and a dim, docile and dependent nature which suits them only for cooking, cleaning and rearing children. I happen to have a much higher regard for my sex than a lot of men apparently do.

This brings me to raise the question why, if so many men say 'We have a tremendously high regard for women; we clearly love our wives and respect them in their role as home makers, child nurturers', and so on, and extol the virtues of the home maker-if home care and child rearing is so important; it has such high status in the community-men entrust it to a species which they so clearly feel does not have the capacity to administer laws, run a business, take on the spiritual welfare of Christians or generally to participate in the development and running of society. Indeed, I wonder why, if home making has such a high status, a lot more men do not undertake it. I believe that, only when parenting is shown as one option for both men and women with other options also being depicted in the books, newspapers and role models that our children are shown from a very young age, will our children truly have the equal opportunity and the right to choose their employment options. Only then will society itself benefit not only from the talents and qualities of men but also from the talents and qualities which women can bring through their intellect and ability to society as a whole.

The Sex Discrimination Bill which is before us today is not, as some people assert, about wrenching babies from the breasts of their mothers and shoving them in some impersonal government funded child minding centre while the woman is forced, more or less at gunpoint, whether she likes it or not, to go out into the work force. What it is about is acknowledging both the rights and the need of many women to work in the paid work force and the necessity to provide appropriate high standard child care facilities to enable them to do that. This Bill is not about giving a woman a job regardless of talent because of her sex and depriving a better qualified man of a job.
At this stage, I refer back to the New South Wales Institute of Public Affairs document which states:
The Bill does nothing to help unemployment and may well make it worse as male breadwinners lose their jobs to more highly qualified women.

I would have thought, first of all, that it was in the interests of business and the development of society generally to make sure that the most highly qualified person available got the job. Secondly, I wonder whether the extension of this is not to say that a male breadwinner should not lose his job to a more highly qualified single man or a man who has no dependent children. What the Bill is in fact about is ending a practice, which is all too prevalent in Australia at the moment, of giving a man a job in preference to a woman regardless of the qualifications of either of them and generally coming down purely and simply on the side of his sex. Nor, I might add, is this Bill about a quota system. It is not attemping to force on either the public sector or the private sector a situation in which it has to employ 50 per cent of women or the Government will take away its industry assistance or the other grants it receives. What it is about is ending discriminatory practices which preclude women from having ever equal access to some jobs in the paid work force. Nor, as I have already said, is the Bill aimed at breaking up family life as we know it, or rather family life as some 25 per cent of the population knows it. It is not designed either to denigrate marriage or to denigrate either men or women who choose to devote their lives to the home making, child caring role. It is designed to give those women who want it or those women who have no option but to choose it the right and opportunity to achieve personal and financial independence.

The Bill does not, of course, aim to produce a uni-sex population but to give to both sexes the right to develop their talents for the betterment of society and according to the qualities that they have as persons, with no denigration and no criticism from society regardless of what their choice is. It might, therefore, mean that women will no longer be seen as child-bearing drudges only and that both parents will look to sharing the responsibility for rearing children. Above all, I suggest that the Bill acknowledges that women are born with both a brain and a womb. Anybody who thinks about the matter at all will be aware that our brains remain productive and creative for a darn sight longer than our wombs do. Therefore, when one looks at the role of woman in society one ought to pay equal attention to the role of her mind and the role of her uterus.

As I said in opening my speech, I feel that the Bill does not go far enough. It fails to do a number of things that supporters of the elimination of discrimination against women would like it to do. It does not, for instance, end discriminatory practices against women in the private sector. Indeed, even had Senator Ryan included her affirmative action section, it would not have done that since all that section required the private sector to do was to examine its employment practices to see whether it was wittingly or unwittingly indulging in discriminatory practices. Neither, for all that it has a very large sexual harassment sector, does it eliminate the hostile working environment for women, nor the sometimes subtle sexual harassment by colleagues, things which are just as likely to affect a woman's job opportunities at a particular site as harassment from an immediate employer.

I hope that, perhaps, it will finish up ending the perpetration of the view, which is very prevalent in society still, that a woman's place is in the home unless she is some sort of oddity. At the very least I hope it will have some sort of propaganda value in that regard. I would like to refer to the document which Senator Gareth Evans introduced into the Senate last night. It is a discussion paper on the 52 amendments that the Government has introduced either for drafting reasons of its own, for policy reasons of its own or in response to the amendments that were foreshadowed both by the Liberal Opposition and by me on behalf of the Australian Democrats. On page 3 of that document the Government indicates that it has made an amendment relating to exemptions for educational institutions. Senator Evans's paper states:

The Government amendment will provide a further exemption where education at the level at which the applicant is seeking education is provided only or mainly for students of the opposite sex. This is intended to cover situations where, for example, schools are primarily single sex but operate on a co-educational basis at some level.

I sympathise with the Government's intention there. There are a number of schools which are co-educational at the primary level but not at the secondary level and which wish to remain so. I am concerned, though, at a problem which I have raised with both Senator Ryan and the Attorney-General's Department that this may have some unlooked-for consequences at tertiary education level where, for instance, a particular university faculty may use this to deny women the opportunity to study, say, engineering because at that level the subject is mainly undertaken by men. I was pleased that the Government picked up some of our concerns under the sexual harassment provisions and tightened them up.

The Government indicates that its amendments to the section of sport should accommodate some of the concerns raised by the Australian Democrats, but I am not exactly sure whether they in fact achieve that end. The Government will move an amendment to limit the exemption in relation to sport by providing that persons of either sex can be excluded from any competitive sporting activity where the strength, stamina or physique of competitors is relevant. The Government does say that it is of the view that this would encompass an amendment that I suggest-that sporting teams in which the participants were under the age of 12 should not be able to exclude one sex or another. It seems to me that that is very important since it is fairly well known that attitudes to role stereotypes are developed frequently at the primary school level and that at the same time it is at that very stage that girls are likely to be stronger, faster, smarter, and so on, than boys and that if they are entitled to engaged in sporting competition it will make it even easier to dispel the myths that surround women at post-puberty levels that they cannot engage in competitive sport against men.

Certainly the amendment relating to clubs picks up our concern about the rights of both men and women to have access to the various memberships, at golf clubs in particular. It seems to me that there are many men who would be quite prepared to give up their right to play golf on Saturday mornings if they could become associates and pay a bit less.

There is no doubt in my mind that the majority of hysterical outbursts against the legislation are coming in fact from two vested interest groups. The first of those groups consists entirely of men who, with considerable justification, feel threatened; who can see the end of that nice comfortable existence they have always led and come to depend on; and who realise that when women can compete with them on an equal footing they themselves are likely to be found deficient. The second group of complaints tends to be coming from women in a very privileged position; women who have husbands of some considerable wealth; who enjoy manipulating their menfolk, who see the power behind the throne system as being the one that best suits them; who are in fact able to take advantage of their situation and can wield this behind the scenes power to their advantage and, at the same time, lead a nice comfortable and, I suggest with some respect, often parasitic existence in the home.

There is no question, either, that double standards have been the single biggest barrier against equal opportunity for the development of women. These double standards have ranged from the sexual to the occupational, from the domestic to the economic. It cannot be allowed to continue. I suggest that slavery is slavery, whether it takes place on a cotton plantation or on a pedestal. Until women have the right to be independent financially as well as personally, until we have the right to be seen as whole individuals, until we are entitled and not just allowed to make our own decisions regarding our destiny, whether those decisions would see us as a home maker or a law maker or anything else, until the stage where women who want to be people are entitled to be people is reached, I suggest there will be no such thing as equality for women in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I situate this debate in its context by saying first of all that the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 emerges as a result of an international treaty ratified by the Government of Australia. That treaty, of course, is the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women.
—That is the basis of it.

—That is, in fact, the basis of it. This Bill indicates that its objective inter alia is to give effect to certain provisions of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. Of course, much of the campaign over the early part of this year asking parliamentarians not to vote for the ratification of the treaty was misguided because at present Parliament does not have any power over the ratification or signing of a treaty. One of the causes of the confusion has been that very fact and the fact that the Government has not detailed to the Parliament its interpretation of the many articles of that Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: Naturally, there was a good reason for concern amongst the community, because for as many people who have looked at the articles of the Convention there are almost as many interpretations. I believe that that is a failing of the Government. The Government should have placed before the Parliament its interpretation of the articles in the Convention. No doubt, because the Government has signed the Convention, it has a detailed interpretation of the articles of the Convention on file. I give notice to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) that when we come to debate the Schedule of the Bill I will be asking her, article by article, for the interpretation that the Government places on each one of those articles before I am prepared to vote for this measure because the Convention is, in fact, part of the Schedule to the Act and the object of the Act is to implement certain provisions of the Convention. I will show later why it is most important that we have that interpretation. If we do not have the interpretation of the Convention placed in the Bill, the measures in the Bill will be interpreted by a non-elected, non-judicial sex discrimination commissioner.

I believe that I have a right, as an elected representative in this Parliament, to know what I am voting for before I vote for it and should not have to leave the interpretation of this measure to some non-elected, non-judicial sex discrimination commissioner whose qualification for the job presumably will be a long track record of radical feminism.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister's interpretation would have no legal standing.

—If we look at court judgments we see that that could well be, because the Minister's second reading speech and explanatory memoranda of legislation are taken into account by judges in determining cases relating to legislation. I believe that ministerial replies at the Committee stage are now more frequently taken into account. That is one of the problems with which we are faced. That is one of the reasons I have foreshadowed the introduction of legislation to ensure that, prior to a government acceding to, signing or ratifying treaties, those treaties-apart from secret treaties-are laid before both Houses of Parliament and receive the endorsement of both Houses of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the ratification by the Government of the international treaty-the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women- requests were made for the Government to make reservations to some articles of the treaty. The Government did make a few reservations, but not many. A number of people, including myself, suggested that some of the articles were capable of quite radically different interpretations. Indeed, a group of women, namely the Women's Action Alliance, in the 1980s requested the Government to consider appropriate reservations which I believe would have eliminated many of the problems parliamentarians and the Government have faced over this issue. This Bill is to be discussed in that context.

The Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 is a clumsy and to my mind an inexact and unimaginative attempt to give effect to certain provisions of the United Nations treaty. In addition, and perhaps more importantly, the Bill contains provisions which are inconsistent with principles of justice and equality. It gives me no pleasure to say that, because I certainly have a vested interest-I declare it now-in the equality of women, because there happen to be seven women in the household in which I live. Women as defined in this Bill are females of any age. Furthermore, I suppose that of the people in this chamber I am the only one to have had experience in establishing sex discrimination committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you are not. I chaired the Western Australian committee.
—I am sorry. I acknowledge that. I supported the establishment of and served on, those committees.
—That proves that you do not have to be a radical feminist to get a guernsey on those committees.

—Of course not. I was fighting for the rights of women before the radical feminists entered the argument. Let me tell honourable senators what the radical feminists and the pro-communist Left did in 1969 at the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress. They supported an amendment to the equal pay amendment which was recommended by us on the ACTU Executive. The ACTU Executive recommended to the Congress that we fight for the principle of equal pay for work of equal value. The radical feminists at that Congress, supported by the pro-communist left, tried to amend that to the principle of equal pay for equal work. That is significant because it shows what they think about the differences between men and women. Fortunately, we in the ACTU Executive won the day-only narrowly, but we won-so that women do not have to be virtual hermaphrodites to get equal pay. I took one of the first equal pay test cases in Australia and won it.

SPEECH.PARA: It gives me no pleasure to say what I just said about the fact that this Bill is, in my view, an inexact and unimaginative attempt to give effect to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women, imperfect though that is, and that it contains provisons inconsistent with the principles of justice and equality. I also assert, because I know it is a fact, that some of the provisions of the legislation even misinterpret the United Nations Convention. Let me give honourable senators an example. One of the objects of the Bill is to eliminate discrimination against persons on the grounds of marital status in a number of areas, including education and accommodation. The Bill defines marital status to include a de facto relationship. Let us suppose that a married teacher entered into a de facto relationship with a senior student in a school and that it was a matter of public scandal within the school community. Let us suppose that the principal, the other teachers and the parents insisted on their rights to preserve a school environment conducive to the development, including the moral development, of the children. Under the legislation that is now before us, the principal and the parents would be discriminators and liable to action and damages.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they sacked the teacher.

—If they did something about the matter and insisted on a policy. In order not to be discriminatory on that ground, what the Government now says in clause 31A is that, first of all, the discriminator, namely the principal, has to admit that he has discriminated, has to prove that he has done it in good faith and that the act of discrimination is in accordance with the doctrines of a religion or creed under which the educational institution has been established. That imposes farcical and totally unreasonable tests on the rights of parents to insist that schools provide an environment conducive to the moral development of their children. I defy anybody here to say that Catholic schools are established for the provision of education or training in accordance with the doctrine of a religion or creed. That is absolute nonsense. Also, it will give the DOGS a real field day. It will put the meat on their bone if these farcical and unreasonable tests are required by a non-elected, non-judicial sex discrimination commissioner. In addition, I will ask the Minister on what constitutional grounds 'marital status' is defined to include the term 'de facto spouse of another person'. Does anybody know under what constitutional grounds that phrase appears in the Bill? If the Minister says that it is there under the external affairs power, he should have another think about it.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1977 I happened to be at the United Nations as the political adviser from this Parliament. At that stage the draft of the Convention was being considered. The draft at that time mentioned discrimination against women whether married or unmarried. Then in the third session someone on the drafting committee came along and said: 'Well, what about divorcees and separated wives?' The words ' married and unmarried' were changed to 'marital status'. No mention at all was made of de factos. The Government had better have another think about the grounds on which it defined the term 'marital status', unless it is going to rely on the marriage power, which would be most extraordinary in the extreme. I will leave that matter, because there are plenty more things I want to say about it at the Committee stage. I am probably carrying on a Committee stage debate now.

The Government has 52 amendments to this legislation. The Government's amendments to this Bill will not enable me as a parliamentarian with a desire to honour a genuine commitment to both sex discrimination legislation and the preservation of pro-life values to vote for this Bill. I invite the Government to give due consideration to that factor. I invite the Government to declare that its amended Bill cannot and will not be used to widen the scope for deliberately procured abortions. We heard Senator Tate talk about this matter. I invite him and all other honourable senators to read and examine thoroughly the legal advice which has been circulated by Mr Smith from the New South Wales Right to Life Association. If they do not have a copy, I will table the document after my speech.

It is clear indeed from the document and from the responses of the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) that that position is arguable. Given the fact, as has been genuinely stated by Senator Tate and inferred by Senator Gareth Evans, that this Bill is not meant to play into the hands of the pro- abortionists, I invite them to consider applying it to the Bill as a whole. Unless they do so, certainly clause 24 of the Bill will have quite devastating effects, for example, on hospitals governed by the Capital Territory Health Commission. This would also affect nurses and doctors in public hospitals who have conscientious objections to performing certain operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have a look at the wording if you concede the good faith of the Government in this matter.

—Thank you. I do. I accept that. In addition, I believe that at the Committee stage we have to have a good look at a number of other sections in the Bill. I feel we must not involve schools in endless, damaging litigation and put the rights of parents to unreasonable and farcical tests.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to another aspect of this matter. I am concerned about the fact that the interpretation of the legislation could be left in the hands of a sex discrimination commissioner-a non-elected, non-judicial person. In respect of the matter about which I have just spoken, I invite Senator Tate, the Attorney- General and others to examine Articles 12, 14 and 16 of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, which is attached to the Bill and see what sort of a field day a pro-abortionist would have if one were nominated to that position. Whilst talking about matters relating to complaints laid before the Sex Discrimination Commissioner I mention that the provisions of the Bill create an undue burden of proof. When matters are taken before the Sex Discrimination Commissioner there are certain findings of fact. When I have raised this matter before people have said: 'You have a right of appeal to the Federal Court of Australia'. There are two problems in that. One of the problems is in the Bill itself; that is, when the matter, as I understand it, goes to the Federal Court the onus of proof rests with the alleged discriminator. That person has to prove that those findings of fact are not correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite right.

—This reverses the onus of proof; that is right. I note the interjection of the former Attorney-General indicating that that is correct. There is the added problem-particularly now that the Government is seeking to move amendments to the effect that the inquiries by the Human Rights Commission or its delegate are to be in public-of the right of an alleged discriminator not to incriminate himself or herself. Surely this is a matter that must be of concern to civil libertarians in this chamber. I have not had a chance as yet to look at the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Maybe that Committee has made some comment about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators must be aware of the fact that this legislation is only part of what may be coming down the track. Yesterday I read in the Press that the Green Paper to be delivered by the Government on affirmative action has been delayed yet again. We had been given to understand by the Government that we would have that Green Paper some time in September this year. It presumably exists, but I have not seen it and it has not been tabled in Parliament. Presumably it has been prepared. Why does the Government not table the document so that we know what is around the corner and so that we do not buy a pig in a poke? Why hide the thing under the table and get the Parliament to pass this legislation without knowing the full ramifications of it and of what is coming down the track? I challenge the Government to be open about it. It has been prepared. The Government should come out into the open and give us its views on affirmative action because, if those views are simply to pander to the tastes of an elitist group, I believe we ought to know that now. If those views on affirmative action would force, through economic pressure, those mothers who desire to do what they see their most important job in life into the paid work force where no jobs are available, then let us hear them now. This piece of legislation will not create one job. Yes, it will. It will create the job of sex discrimination commissioner and an army of bureaucrats. But it will not do anything for the 23 per cent of young girls now out of work. The figure for boys , I think, is 22.9 per cent. We are facing, in addition to that 23 per cent, those who will be thrown on the scrapheap after they leave school. As a parent my main concern and that of anybody listening to this debate is about jobs for girls. I am concerned about jobs for my family, but this legislation will not create them. In fact, if the affirmative action which I understand is proposed, including the proposals to have economic pressure-

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a piece of human rights legislation, not job creation.
—Senator Giles is on record as being against the spouse rebate .
—That is right.

—Yes, Senator Giles says that is right. What will that do? Senator Giles admits she is against the spouse rebate. She wants to take 16 bucks a week from some workers in Australia and force the spouses of workers into the paid work force. That is why I want to see what is coming down the track. That is why I want to see the affirmative action proposals laid before this Parliament before this legislation is passed. To be concerned about people losing 16 bucks a week is not hysterical nonsense. It is not hysterical nonsense to be concerned for a mother who has raised a family and who has done a very good job in the community being forced into the paid work force. There are many voluntary agencies who welcome her assistance. Let us not have from Senator Ryan 's office false interpretations of matters I have attempted to deal with in a logical and reasonable way, because when we come to deal with exemptions under this legislation we must ensure that they are correct and will cover the situation. As Senator Tate will know, the effect of the Acts Interpretation Act when applied to the objects of the legislation-namely, to eliminate so far as possible discrimination against a person on the ground of sex, et cetera-is that discrimination will be interpreted in the widest possible manner and exemptions will be interpreted in the narrowest possible manner. Let us not forget that point when we talk about amendments to this legislation. An article in the Canberra Times of 7 October, dealing with the circulation of a paper by the New South Wales Right to Life Association, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan's spokeswoman said last night that the arguments were not considered plausible by lawyers in the Attorney-General's Department.
I contacted the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, and he wrote me a letter on 18 October which states:

You asked me by phone who were the lawyers in the Attorney-General's Department who, according to the Canberra Times of 7 October, did not consider the arguments in the New South Wales Right to Life paper to be plausible. I have ascertained that, at the time of the Canberra Times report, there had been no consideration by any officer of this Department of the New South Wales Right to Life paper and no views were expressed about it by them.
I ask that sensible consideration be given to matters by the Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sex Discrimination Bill is a very significant step towards Australia becoming a more just and equitable society. For a long time Australians have been discriminated against in a number of ways and on a number of grounds, but I think that in 1983 the most common ground of discrimination is that of sex. Surely in a country which regards itself as fair and democratic we can no longer condone practices which penalise or reward on grounds other than the capacity to do a required task, whether it be work, study , or paying off a loan. Some of the discrimination prohibited by this Bill may seem minor or unimportant to those who are not affected. Not all of us, for example, want to join a licensed club, but business deals are often settled in them, and a businesswoman is denied the opportunity to take part in that type of business if she is denied membership. Other areas of discrimination, though, have a major effect on the lives of those who suffer from that discrimination- for example, hiring for employment-and therefore also indirectly affect the lives of others such as their children.

SPEECH.PARA: It needs to be emphasised that this is a Bill to deal with discrimination against either sex. The debate in the community has been mainly about women, but the Bill also prohibits discrimination against men. Its provisions apply to both sexes. Although only women can become pregnant, the effects of discrimination on the ground of pregnancy may disadvantage men as well; for example, if a woman is the partial or total breadwinner for the family. So much emphasis in the public debate has been put on the status of women that I should like to give three examples of discrimination against men which can be redressed under this legislation. At present many men are denied jobs which are traditionally regarded as female, such as those of secretary or pre-school teacher. I have had letters claiming that employers should keep the right to hire an attractive female secretary. Is that not discrimination against men?

At present a man may be denied promotion on the ground of marital status. Many executive positions are reserved for married men who are thought, perhaps erroneously, to be more stable employment prospects and whose wives can do the company entertaining usually free of charge. Men are also frequently discriminated against as tenants. Landlords and landladies apparently believe that women are better at maintaining properties. Notwithstanding what I have said, women certainly have more to gain from this legislation than men.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested to know what constitutional ground the latter would be.

—I do not have time to go into that matter now. It is in the legislation. The most important area of discrimination against women is in employment. The Women's Bureau of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has published figures on women at work for 1983. These show that for every year since 1966 female rates of unemployment have been higher than male. In August 1982, 7.4 per cent of females were unemployed compared with 6.3 per cent of males. The average time unemployed was also considerably longer for females. In part time employment, females far outnumber males. Part time positions are often inferior in conditions, pay rates and certainly in promotional opportunities. Some women certainly prefer to work part time-this fits in with their family arrangements-but many more do so simply because they cannot get full time work. The Women's Bureau paper, to which I have referred, shows that among those classified as discouraged workers-the people who have given up trying although they still do want work-87.6 per cent were female.

SPEECH.PARA: So women are disadvantaged in the area of work. Some of the reasons lie in the area of education. I will come to that later. Other reasons lie at the point of hiring and in lack of opportunity for promotion. Over the years the barriers to employment have been slowly and painfully lowered for women. But they still find it very difficult to enter occupations which are traditionally the preserve of males. The traditionally female jobs are often the hardest hit by technological change; the most glaring example is what has happened to the copy typist in recent years. Females find it very hard to enter most of the skilled trades. In June 1982 females totalled only 6 per cent of all apprentices and most of those apprentices were learning hairdressing. Only 1.3 per cent of the 6 per cent were electrical apprentices and 0.2 of a per cent were vehicle trade apprentices.

In February 1982, the unemployment rate for females with post-school qualifications-those who had finished school and gone on to something further- was nearly three times that of males with the same qualifications. Women are also discriminated against in promotion. Women are under-represented at the higher levels of most professions, such as the Australian Public Service, banking and the law. Female teachers far outnumber male teachers but there are very few female principals and even fewer female professors. There are reasons, other than discrimination, accounting for part of the variance, such as different parental expectations for their children and the effect that that has on school retention rates. But discrimination is rife in both hiring and promotion. It is not always even conscious on the part of the employer. One of the shocks I have had delivered in letters I have received on this Bill is that some people, usually male, genuinely believe that women are inherently or, as sometimes stated, by God's will, to be less intelligent, strong, persistent, logical and committed. I can name any of those desirable characteristics for an employee and I will find it in the letters there. In this case, discriminatory behaviour is not perceived, as such, by the person who is discriminating. Even when it is conscious it is often covert. For example, the sort of thing that happens is that the applicants with female names just do not get interviews.

Related to the provisions of the Bill covering employment is the provision concerning advertising which, among other things, prohibits the publication of advertisements indicating an intention to practise discrimination; the sort of advertisement which specifies a male or a female. It comes as a shock to young women seeking employment that they are debarred from jobs still anachronistically tagged for males. It does not do much for their self esteem if they are trained for a job, and have perhaps done better than the males in the training course, to find that the job is mainly reserved for the opposite sex. When women are not seen to be employed in a particular career it has an effect back in the schools. That job is not perceived as being available to females, so subject choices are not geared in that direction. My own State has, for some years, prohibited advertising for sex tagged positions such as Girl Fridays. Honourable senators should just think of the connotations of that job description. Yet I do not think anyone has noticed a unisex society developing in Victoria as some critics predicted.

The Bill also prohibits discrimination in services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans or credit. Women often have to battle for the right to simple things such as charge accounts and minor loans. A female friend of mine recently inquired about a loan to buy a secondhand car. She was asked not only about her marital status but also whether she intended to become pregnant and, if so, when-this to buy a secondhand car. She bought her car elsewhere. This Bill aims to prevent that sort of discriminatory practice, which particularly affects single women seeking housing loans.

The other area of discrimination to which I refer is that of education. This Government is committed to a policy of participation and equity in education, and this Bill will help us to implement that policy. There are still many schools at which students are discriminated against in their choice of subjects on the grounds of sex and again I refer to both sexes. Punishment is often handled in a discriminatory way. I believe that there are schools which exclude pregnant students. It is suspected that some tertiary courses include gender in their criteria for selecting students. Course advisers sometimes discourage girls from applying for traditional male courses, such as geology and surveying. This Bill will increase the range of educational opportunities available for females.

A very important part of the Bill deals with sexual harassment in the work place or in educational institutions. Sexual harassment is defined as 'making an unwelcome sexual advance', 'a request for sexual favours' or 'engaging in unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature in relation to the other person'. It becomes discriminatory under the terms of the legislation when the person harassed has reasonable grounds for believing that refusal, rejection or objection to that behaviour would disadvantage him or her in respect of work or potential work or when that disadvantage actually occurs. There is confusion, I know, in some people's minds about the meaning of harassment. It refers only to unwelcome behaviour and usually to situations in which the harasser has some power over the harassed. Conduct of a sexual nature, as referred to in the Bill, includes oral or written statements such as messages left on typewriters or sexual remarks made about a person in their hearing as well as more obvious sorts of sexual conduct. A similar definition is given for sexual harassment in education covering disadvantage in admission to an educational institution or in study there. The most common example would probably be where the grade level given to a student is made dependent on sexual favours granted, commonly referred to among students as 'an A for a lay'.

Many men seem to believe that sexual harassment is, at most, a minor or infrequent phenomenon. Males, of course, are certainly not immune from sexual harassment, but women are very aware of its prevalence. This Bill deals only with harassment which is discriminatory in hiring or promotion at work, in enrolment or assessment and education. In such situations sexual harassment is a form of blackmail-the use of power to obtain sexual gratification which, until recent years, was little talked about. State legislation against discrimination and the development of support systems among women have brought more of this behaviour under scrutiny, but legal procedures to deal with it have been lacking , in addition to the social constraints which keep such offences, as with sexual assault, largely hidden. The few cases which have received publicity have taken place at work. Successful or not, the penalties for women who are prepared to take their cases to court are great. I admire those brave enough to take this step. I suspect harassment is just as prevalent in education, particularly at senior secondary and tertiary level. There are academics, for example, against whom known complaints, let alone those unreported, run into double figures. To prohibit sexual harassment is to prohibit something which is anti-social and causes a great deal of stress and injustice.

There are many exemptions from the provisions of this Bill-indeed, as has been referred to before, more than some of us would wish. I believe those exemptions now meet all reasonable objections. During community discussion on the Bill, as with discussion on the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women with which it is linked, it has become clear that many of those voicing objections have not read or fully understood its provisions. Indeed, I would say from the handwriting on some of the petitions I have received that those signing are too young to be able either to read or to understand it. Perhaps because this Bill will help to break down many entrenched barriers to equality of the sexes it is being opposed so strongly, on such misinformed and sometimes malicious grounds, by a very vocal, well-organised minority. These people apparently wish to perpetuate a society in which people are excluded or handicapped in careers, education and recreation, et cetera, purely by accident of birth in that they happen to be born of one sex or the other.

I would like to refer now to two of the false claims being circulated about the effects of this legislation, most of which were very adequately and well dealt with by Senator Haines earlier. This Bill is not anti-family. There is nothing in it to justify that label. Improved access to education should produce mothers better able to assist their children's development. Indeed, this Bill promotes the growth of the family as a more equitable grouping and thus a happier one by presenting a model in society which I hope will be followed in behaviour at home . I am sure we all know of marriages which have broken down because internal relationships have become insupportable for a partner who is treated as less than equal by the other partner. Nor will the Bill stop people having children. The removal of discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy may even encourage childbearing by removing the pressure in the work place not to become pregnant for fear of discrimination. The lessening of discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy will further delineate the separation of people's private from their public lives-surely a progressive step in any just and pluralistic society. I have been horrified to find that some opponents of this Bill believe, as did our forebears in less enlightened times, that the private lives of employees should be liable to scrutiny by employers.

Clauses 45 and 61 to 64 relating to the treatment of complaints represent a very progressive step in Australian legal development as they allow representative complaints, a type of class action which is not currently available in the Australian judicial system. Such a procedure will enhance the principle of equality before the law by establishing the rights, or in this case redressing the complaints, of people who could not afford the time or money to take legal action as individuals. Allowing representative complaints could mean rapid change where a commissioner upholds a complaint because a large group of people could benefit from that decision at the one time and, therefore, achieve speedier quick redress; for example, a group of women denied promotion from low paid jobs or women students in a particular course. The power for a complaint to be lodged by someone other than the victim is very important because it will lessen the obvious risk taken by the complainant-the risk of future victimisation even if the initial battle is won.

I welcome the education and research functions given to the Human Rights Commission. This has been very valuable in those States where similar legislation is in force. Commissioners are able to perform a valuable educative role with groups who might otherwise act in a discriminatory way, such as employers or teachers. More importantly, in speaking to groups of school students, community groups, unions and so on I have found that they are able to make victims or potential victims of discrimination aware of their rights. No legislation of this nature can be really effective if those it seeks to help are unaware of its existence. As similar legislation has done in some States, this Bill provides a relatively simple process for complaint. A simple and non- threatening complaint process is essential if the Bill is to be effective in preventing and redressing discrimination. In 1983 we should not tolerate the fact that Australia has any second class citizens. This Bill takes an historic step towards removing areas of discrimination between those who should be treated as equal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 has attracted vocal criticism. It is difficult to estimate the extent of the apparent disquiet because the volume of representations to honourable senators is not necessarily indicative of general community feeling. However, it is clear that there is a significant group of Australians who are deeply and genuinely concerned about the proposed legislation. Their worries demand careful consideration. Certain of those worries, such as the purpose of the Bill and the policy of anti-discrimination legislation, may be said to operate at a philosophical level. Another series of objections relate to the content of the Bill. They are questions about whether the principles of natural justice have been observed, the effect upon church and other private schools and whether the drafting has been such as to infringe upon what we are told are other non- intended policy areas such as abortion.

SPEECH.PARA: In this speech I wish to refer to the Bill in principle. If it receives a second reading I wish to contribute to the subject of its content at the Committee stage because I believe it has very real deficiencies. Criticisms based on philosophy have tended to be as follows: That the legislation will undermine the family unit; that it will destroy the traditional concept of the family; that it will lessen the traditional respect accorded to women as homemakers; that it virtually consigns marriage to irrelevance; and that it will drive women who are totally satisfied with their role as wife and mother, sustainer and supporter, and upbringer of children to outside employment, against their wishes, and their children to creches. These are obviously serious and very emotive charges calling for answers.

I have attempted to take cognisance of all representations. I have studied the Bill carefully, read the views of many commentators and tried to analyse the subject with an open mind. It is impossible to analyse Bills in a total vacuum. We all must have certain prejudices. We all must be influenced by our backgrounds, our education, our personal experiences and the experiences of our friends and acquaintances. I am on the record in this place as supporting the traditional family. I have expressed my concern at the degree of family and marital breakdown. I have looked at the factors causing family distress, particularly unemployment and financial difficulties, and have looked at ways in which we can support the family structure through such avenues as tax reform, support for marriage guidance, family counsellors and the like. However, I also recognise that many, through choice and no choice, do not live in a traditional family and they are equally entitled to my respect and concern.

I have other prejudices. I have faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human purpose and in the equal rights of men and women. That is taken from the United Nations Charter. I believe that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms without distinction of any kind, including distinction based on sex. That is taken from the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I support the equal right of men and women to enjoy all economic, social , cultural, civil and political rights. I remind the Senate that that is an obligation of States under the International Covenant on Human Rights. All honourable senators will know that it was in the light of such declarations- despite such basic statements of principle extensive discrimination against women continues to exist-that the convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women came into being. Therefore, a convention with that objective would prima facie accord with my prejudice and, I think, would have the support of all Australians, male or female. Before someone says that extensive discrimination against women no longer exists, I remind the Senate of the words of the program of action for the second half of the United Nations Decade for Women:

While (women) represent 50 per cent of the world adult population and 1/3 of the official labour force, they perform for nearly 2/3 of all working hours and receive only 1/10 of the world's income and own less than 1 per cent of world property.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debated adjourned.
