TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I inform the Senate that Senator Gareth Evans will be absent from the chamber today. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his portfolio should be directed to me, and any questions relating to the portfolios that Senator Evans represents in this chamber should be directed to Senator Grimes. I also remind the Senate of Senator Gietzelt's absence and ask that any questions for him be directed to Senator Grimes.

—Perhaps I may preface my question by saying that if the Government insists on Friday sittings, we think that it should at least have the courtesy to produce the Ministers for the normal parliamentary forms. My question is directed to Senator Button as the Prime Minister's representative, as the Minister directly responsible for government relations with business and industry, and as a reported participant in the meeting on Wednesday at which Mr Hawke backed down from his commitment to the Roxby Downs project and new contracts for the Ranger and Nabarlek uranium mines which Mr Hawke gave directly to businessmen and through the pages of a business oriented magazine. Does the Minister agree that the reports which appeared in two leading newspapers this morning will seriously damage the credibility of the Prime Minister in particular and of the Government generally with the business community in the light of the clear statements that Mr Hawke has made on this matter to them?

—I do not agree that the reports which appeared in newspapers will damage the standing or reputation of the Prime Minister with the business community. They might, in fact, damage the journalists who wrote them when the Government finally makes a decision on this matter. As I have indicated on a number of occasions, and as Senator Walsh and others have indicated in this chamber, the Government is reviewing its policy in relation to uranium mining. When that review is completed the Government will make decisions and will make an announcement about those decisions. Any gossip in newspapers about purported private conversations is not assisting the Government to make those decisions and is not damaging in any way except to those people who report those alleged discussions without any substantial basis in fact.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of that answer, I ask the Minister whether the business community of Australia can rely on the statement made by the Prime Minister to the Business Council of Australia that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . as far as our government is concerned-
the Federal Government and the Government of South Australia, the Roxby development is going ahead and nothing is going to stop that.
I ask the Minister again: Can people rely on that statement as a statement of fact?

TALK.START.PARA: —The business community in Australia can rely on the fact that the Government will make a decision about these matters in the next week or two and that decision will be announced. As to the honourable senator's question about Roxby Downs, there is no member of the business community in Australia who is concerned that this matter should be addressed in the Senate today rather than on the Government's decision in a week or two's time.

—I preface my question by noting that there are three shadow Ministers missing today. Nevertheless, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications: Is it a fact that Telecom Australia has people working full time to assist police in their drive against illegal bookmakers? Is it true that Telecom cannot allow State police to use call record printers because it would be illegal for it to do under the Telecommunications ( Interception) Act? Finally, is it practical, as suggested by Special Prosecutor Redlich, that Telecom should question the purpose for which a telephone service will be used?

—I am able to answer the first part of the question. It is a fact, as I understand it, that Telecom employees are working full time in relation to the inquiries which are being conducted by the police involving the use of telephones for illegal purposes. It is also a fact, as I understand it, that under the legislation Telecom cannot at the moment allow State police to use the mechanisms which Senator Ray in his question described more eloquently than I can describe in the answer. With regard to the third part of his question, I am not familiar with Mr Redlich's comments and the extract which is taken out of the context of the report. I will address that part of the question to the Minister for Communications and see whether I can supply an early answer for Senator Ray.

—I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. Does the preliminary analysis by the Minister's Department of questionnaire replies from pensioners over 70 years of age reveal that substantial numbers of such pensioners are entitled to full pensions but are currently drawing only the frozen over-70s pension? Is it a fact that this analysis also shows that most pensioners of all categories are earning more than 10 per cent on their investments which, as a result of the proposed assets test, will entitle them to higher pensions than they are presently receiving? By contrast, will pensioners with modest, but legitimate, low yielding investments such as farms, find their pension reduced and hence their capital eroded by the same 10 per cent test on assets proposed by the Labor Government? Would the Minister agree that the likely overall effect of this will be to increase rather than reduce the cost of providing old age pensions? If so, how can he claim that these changes are for the benefit of the most needy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assessment of the forms which have been sent out to and so far have been returned by people who are over 70 and who come under the new income test has revealed that some people-I am uncertain of the numbers at the moment but I will try to get the exact numbers-who previously were on the frozen rate pension should have been on a higher pension or the full pension. I think that is one side effect which we knew would happen with the introduction of the new over-70s income test. I will find out, when the full assessment has been carried out, just how many are involved. However, I think it is important that people who were entitled to more than they were getting should get those higher pensions. These people obviously are in need and I am glad that they will get their entitlement. I think it is important that they should do so.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Messner asked a question about the assets test. Certainly, there will be people who have put their money into legitimate investments, such as Australian bonds and power loans, for which they have been getting a yield higher than 10 per cent and who would be better off under the assets test than they were under the income test.

From the first announcement, I have said that there will be an assets test. I have repeated that. It is interesting to note the numbers of examples which come up at meetings of where people will in fact be better off under that test. As I have said in this place, we are at the moment formulating the full assets test, the full regulations and the full outline of the test. One thing which is of importance in such formulations, as I have said here in answers to Senator Collard and others, is how we will handle the situation of those who own farms and, in particular, the situation of those who have lived on farms all their lives and wish to stay on in the house on that property while the property is run by a relative.

I have had representations from pensioner organisations, individuals and farmer organisations about this matter. These representations are being taken into consideration at present by the Government and the committees of the Government, and they will be taken into consideration by the Cabinet next week. As a result of those considerations we will make an announcement and introduce legislation which will include the special treatment of people in that situation to make sure that hardship does not occur. If Senator Messner has any suggestions of his own, we are happy to listen even to them. In the meantime, I suggest that rather than cause anxiety amongst people, he should wait until the legislation comes in and for a complete outline of the assets test. We can then have a debate in this place on it based on facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister please address himself to the last part of my question which is whether this will, in fact, lead to increased costs to the social security system and whether it will assist the most needy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, no, the introduction of the assets test will not lead to increased costs to the social security system. The aim of the assets test is to make it a more needs-based system so that we have more money to provide increases in the base rate pension for those who are in most need. As Senator Messner's predecessors came to realise, if a government is in a situation in which large amounts of money are being leached out of the system by people with fixed trusts, et cetera, that government-Labour or Liberal-is unable to raise those base rates of pension.
—But is it going to cost more or less?
—I have said that the assets test, once it is introduced, will result in less expenditure on aged care. Senator Chaney knows this. He was involved in agonising over it for a couple of years himself.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, yes, the test will result in removal of the discrimination which now exists whereby people with large asset holdings can so manipulate those holdings and avoid the income test, whereas people with weekly fixed payments such as superannuation pensions cannot do so and therefore, because of the Government's inability to increase that base rate pension, in fact suffer. That is what it is all about. Senator Messner knows what it is all about, I think, Senator Chaney certainly does.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you just said that it was going to cost more.
—Order! The honourable senator has already asked a supplementary question.

—I suggest that Senator Messner, rather than sitting in this place at Question Time nitpicking and carrying on like a nark, should get to the job he said he would proceed with when he became shadow Minister-that is, for the first time, to develop a comprehensive retirement policy which the Liberal Party can attempt to sell.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Has the Minister seen a report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald which states that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has decided to pay the legal costs for a defamation action against the Premier of New South Wales by one of its senior reporters, Mr Geoffrey Sims? Can the Minister state whether the decision taken by the ABC is within its powers and functions as determined by the Parliament in the provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act? The Acting Chairman of the ABC, Mrs Wendy McCarthy, in her statement this morning was reported as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the ABC board's decision must not be taken as a precedent for further cases.
The terms and conditions of the support have been put to Mr Sims and will be the subject of consultation with Mr Sims' legal advisers . . .
The Board wishes to point out that its decision has been based on the particular circumstances, merits and facts that are currently known.
Do her remarks indicate that the Corporation itself has doubts about the legality of its decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report in the Sydney Morning Herald but the contents of that report have been drawn to my attention. I commence any comment I have to make on this matter by reminding the Senate that the ABC is an independent statutory corporation and it is not for this Government to interfere in the way in which it exercises its functions under its enabling legislation. I take Senator Richardson's question to ask me whether the action of the ABC in this matter is ultra vires in the sense that it is beyond the powers of the corporation of the ABC. I am not proposing to give a legal opinion, I just say that as a layman I would think not.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as the specifics of the question are concerned, I understand that the ABC-that is, the Board or its representatives-has held negotiations on this matter with the Australian Journalists Association and with Mr Sims, the reporter in question. I am asked whether one can place any interpretation on the remarks by the Acting Chairman of the ABC, Mrs Wendy McCarthy, which are reported in the Sydney Morning Herald. I can only say that I decline to do so because the honourable senator's interpretation would be as good as mine or anybody else's. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware that, according to the New York Times of 15 October, the Dow chemical company has abandoned its four-year, $7m effort to justify the use of its product 2,4,5-T and that as a result the use of 2,4,5- T will cease completely in the United States? The Dow company gave its main reason in the New York Times as public anxiety about 2,4,5-T. Did the Minister note that, according to yesterday's Melbourne Age, the Dow chemical company in Australia said it had no intention of withdrawing the chemical from sale in this country, and in the same issue of the Age the Victorian Government said it would not act until it had some instruction from the National Health and Medical Research Council? In view of widespread anxiety about the product's effects in Australia, and its decreasing use in any case by responsible people, will the Minister now seek an urgent, rational and up to date reconsideration of the use of 2,4,5-T here by the National Health and Medical Research Council?

—Yes, I certainly had my attention drawn to the fact that the Dow chemical company had withdrawn from the various cases concerning 2,4,5-T in which it was involved in the United States for many years. It seems that for a long time the company used the very tortuous and complicated court system which exists in the United States to prevent the settlements of those cases. I think they have been mentioned in debate in this place in the past. It is my understanding that the Dow chemical company gave amongst its reasons the anxiety amongst the public that Senator Mason mentioned and also the financial burden that the company was under because of the cases running for such a long time. I have not noted the comments of the Dow chemical company's subsidiary in Australia. I will certainly draw the attention of the Minister for Health to those comments and seek from the Minister the urgent advice for which Senator Mason asks as to where this country should go in regard to the use of 2,4,5-T, and in particular whether the NHMRC should investigate the matter as Senator Mason suggested.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

It refers to a report released this week by an independent review committee which criticised occupational health and safety practices in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Does the Minister believe the criticisms are justified? If so, what action will the Government take to protect the health and safety of workers in the CSIRO?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Zakharov said, a report was released by the CSIRO this week in relation to occupational health and safety in the CSIRO. I remind the Senate that that report was commissioned by the CSIRO itself because it was concerned about a number of aspects of occupational health and safety within that Organisation. The report contains, I believe, a number of quite alarming stories of incidents of lack of care in relation to health and safety aspects of work in the CSIRO. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I direct a question to you. By way of preface I wish to thank you for the statement concerning the electronic sweep which was carried out recently on committee rooms and the assurance you gave that random checks will be made on offices and committee rooms in Parliament House in the future. However, no mention was made of checks on telephones in Parliament House . Is it a fact that the so-called telephone rises installed in Parliament House are easy to tap? QUESTION.PARA: ASIO is believed to have told the Federal Government that professionals wiretapped the office phone of the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, but left the job half-done.
The article went on to say:
The security assessment produced by ASIO is believed to conclude that the wire tappers may have fled after being disturbed while attaching a ''bug'' to telephone lines inside Parliament House.

Following that, I ask: What is being done, or contemplated, to discover the identity of the alleged phone tapper? Is anything being done to improve telephone installations to eliminate or minimise the possibility of electronic interference with telephones in Parliament House?

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has not been drawn to the article in the Melbourne Age from which the honourable senator quoted. As a result, I have to advise that the Speaker of the House of Representatives and I have asked the parliamentary security advisers to consult with Telecom Australia to see what appropriate steps can be taken to ensure the security of the Parliament House telephone system.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Government decided on the new rates of workers compensation payments under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act? Since the rates have been adjusted in a fairly haphazard way under the previous Government, can the Minister give an assurance that ex-workers receiving Commonwealth Government compensation will, in future, be adequately compensated for cost of living rises ?

—I thank Senator Robertson for his question. I am aware that the previous Government was unwilling to upgrade the benefits to its employees who suffered from injury or other stressful situations. Over the years there was a considerable time when, in fact, no increases were provided. I think at one stage the previous Government did not raise those benefits for about three years while wage earners and other pensioners received consumer price index increases and other wage increases. The Government has considered the best way to adjust compensation benefits. It has decided that they should be indexed twice yearly in line with the application of the average weekly earnings index. The application of this percentage increase in average weekly earnings from November 1981 to November 1983 will result in a 4.79 per cent increase in the level of benefits currently payable. That means that the weekly incapacity rate will rise from $134.85 to $141.30 and the death benefit will rise from $42,000 to $42,010 with corresponding increases in other benefits under the Act. In our view this is an appropriate benchmark reflecting, as it does, the earnings-related nature of compensation payments-that is, the regime is based on wages and salaries rather than on the price-related and less predictable consumer price index. Of course, similar increases will be applied to benefits payable under the Seamen's Compensation Act which is a sister Act to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows a reply to a question asked by Senator Chaney in which Senator Button said that the Government was currently reviewing its attitude to uranium mining and export. I ask: During that review will the Government keep in mind the damage being done to this planet by way of acid rain which largely comes from coal burning power stations--
—Not again.
—As reported in today's Australian in an article headed 'Acid rain eating up German forests'?
—There is no comparison.

—Will the Government keep in mind the irreversible damage that could be done to this planet by the rapidly increasing amounts of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere which have the resultant effect of increasing global temperature that will affect not only the northern part of this globe but also the southern part? Will the Minister remind the Government that most scientists and engineers feel that we should stop burning fossil fuel as soon as possible and turn to nuclear power?

—Senator Townley asked me a question about the review currently being conducted-it is becoming a matter of common knowledge to the Senate-by the Government in relation to its uranium mining and export policy. He asked me first of all whether the Government will keep in mind that rain from coal burning power stations contains a number of acids and so on and whether the Government will address that serious problem. In spite of the interjections by my colleague, Senator Georges, I must say that it is an immensely serious problem. The problem is so serious in Europe that I think that, by the end of the century, it is estimated--
—There will be no trees.

—Thank you, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I am getting an awful lot of help here today. By the end of this century, there are likely to be no trees in Europe and, if the interjections go on, I hope there will be no honourable senators here, if we are to be assisted in the way in which I have been in trying to answer this question. Senator Georges interjected and said there was no comparison between these environmental problems and the problems caused by the use of nuclear power. With respect, I think there is a comparison because they both involve important questions of environmental damage. The very real distinction in relation to nuclear power is, of course, the existence and presence of nuclear weapons and the proliferation of nuclear weapons, which is a separate matter. Senator Georges might, in that context, address his attention to the importance of biological weapons as well, I think. All of these factors have to be taken into account. Secondly, I am asked whether the Government will take into account what is called the glasshouse effect.
—Greenhouse.

—It depends on which school of uranium studies one attended. With the greatest respect, it is called the glasshouse effect in the United States and the greenhouse effect amongst this collection of Chauncey Gardiners who constitute the Opposition in the Senate in Australia in 1983. Whether it be the glasshouse effect or the greenhouse effect, the fact remains that that is also an immensely important environmental issue which any government has to address. The present Government, in considering the questions relating to its uranium mining and export policy, will of course have to consider these matters.
—Hear, hear! A very good answer.

—They will be considered and, as Senator Chaney is concerned about this matter and desperately concerned about the plight of worried businessmen in the next week or two in relation to Roxby Downs, the Government will give an answer to these questions in the foreseeable future.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the tax recoupment legislation defeated in the Senate this week. I ask: What further liability, if any, would have been incurred under that legislation by a person who had received an assessment under the 1982 unpaid company tax legislation? Further, will the Minister say whether any and, if so, which, vested interests have been involved in the rejection of this legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Bolkus's first question is that, disregarding the possibility of an assessment below $100, any person who received an assessment pursuant to the 1982 Act would have received an additional assessment pursuant to the Bill rejected by the Senate on Wednesday night had that Bill not been rejected by the Senate. I should like to be able to give Senator Bolkus an assurance that there was no vested personal interest involved by anyone who voted on that legislation but I regret that I cannot give such an assurance. Indeed, it is known that at least one member of the House of Representatives had a personal interest and, until this week, an undisclosed vested interest in defeating the Bill, at the autumn and spring sessions of Parliament. That person abstained from voting on the 1982 legislation and voted against the 1983 Bills in the autumn and spring sessions. The person, of course, was the shadow Minister for Finance. Mr John Moore, who, as the documents that I tabled in the Senate a couple of days ago show, inter alia, became, with W. J. Wilde, now of Coopers and Lybrand but at the time, I believe, a member of another firm and the continuing accountant for Mr Moore, on 31 March 1978, a director of Colinton Pty Ltd. On 24 April 1980, at a Colinton meeting-there were only two directors of the company-it was resolved to transfer the share register from Brisbane to Peat, Marwick, Mitchell and Co. in Darwin.

ANSWER.PARA: On 8 May 1980 the company office was actually moved from Brisbane to Peat, Marwick, Mitchell and Co. of Darwin. On that same day Messrs Moore and Wilde resigned as directors and were replaced by Colin Hally Coghill and John Francis Edwards. They are the same Coghill and Edwards who are identified in the McCabe- Lafranchi report as becoming directors of Treamog Pty Ltd, among other things, on 30 June 1977.

From then on, Colinton Pty Ltd, as was shown in the documents and summary of documents which I tabled earlier this week, went through the assortment of name, directorial and shareholder changes of the classic tax evasion, bottom of the harbour operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is responding to a question about further liability which might be incurred if legislation were passed. He has answered the question. In fact, he did so very accurately in about two sentences. He is now moving on and attempting to involve Mr Moore in matters which transpired after the company in which Mr Moore was interested had been sold by him and after he no longer had any legal interest in or any control over the matter. I put it to you, Mr President, that the only object of this answer now-the question having already been fully answered-is to endeavour to smear a member of the House of Representatives by raising innuendos which are false. I ask you to rule the rest of the answer out of order. I do not believe that it has anything to do with the question which was raised by Senator Bolkus, which was a proper question and which was answered in this place in two sentences.

—I have been following the Minister's remarks carefully. He has not, as yet, offended under standing order 418. I am taking it that the Minister is amplifying his remarks to explain the last portion of the honourable senator' s question. However, I ask the Minister to be restrictive in his remarks and to be mindful of the provisions of standing order 418.

—As always, Mr President, I shall do so. The relevance of Mr Moore to Senator Bolkus's question-and the relevance is direct-is that Mr Moore admitted in the House of Representatives, I think it was on Tuesday evening of this week, that he was in receipt of an assessment from the Commissioner of Taxation pursuant to the 1982 legislation. He, therefore, necessarily- overlooking the $100 clause-would have received an additional assessment if the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 rejected by the Senate on Wednesday night were enacted. The details of this case, tabled on Wednesday, show a classic wet Slutzkin operation. As I said, Mr Moore has acknowledged having received an assessment, although he declined to disclose the amount, pursuant to the 1982 legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two other points I want to make. One is that the directors of the company in question changed directly from Moore and Wilde to Coghill and Edwards . Mr Moore was not ignorant of the identity of the new directors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I again say to you, Mr President, that this matter is of no relevance to the question that was asked and is clearly an attempt to smear a member of the House of Representatives by innuendo. The fact is that whatever classic example this may be, to use the expression of the Minister, the company was sold. What is done with sold property subsequent to sale is a matter that is beyond the control of the vendor . I believe that this is thoroughly objectionable. It is thoroughly typical of what honourable senators have to put up with from Senator Walsh. I believe that it should be ruled out of order.
—I ask the Minister to bear in mind standing order 100 and to bring his remarks to a conclusion.

—It is simply not conceivable that a man with Mr Moore's vast experience as an accountant, stockbroker, share-trader, former Queensland Liberal Party State President and Treasurer, did not know by May 1980 that Coghill and Edwards were bottom of the harbour operators.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The last few words of the Minister make it quite clear what his intention is and what he is doing in this chamber. He is abusing the forms of the Senate. I believe that he should be sat down.

—On the point of order: It is apparent that the question I asked was in two parts. In the second part I asked the Minister to detail any vested interests that might have been involved. The information that the Minister is giving at the moment goes very much to the heart of and is answering that part of the question.

—On the point of order, Mr President: You said that the Minister at one stage was getting near to not complying with standing order 418. But it is clear that the last part of standing order 418 states that 'all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly'. Even if the reflections are entirely true, they are reflections on a person who is not a member of this House. The whole purpose, surely, of that standing order is to protect members of the other House from being smeared in this way. I suggest, sir, that there must be a stage when you must rule in favour of this tactic being out of order.

—On the point of order, no one has as yet asked the Minister to withdraw anything that he has said. But I really think that the Minister has had a fair go and I suggest that he has completed his answer.
—I will very shortly, Mr President. The second point I wanted to make--
—Order! I suggest that the Minister has completed his answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIES ASSISTANCE COMMISSION: REPORT ON POLYVINYL CHLORIDE

The Minister will recall that on 15 June 1983 he asked the Industries Assistance Commission to inquire into and report on certain dumping issues associated with imports of polyvinyl chloride. As part of the terms of reference , the IAC was given a period of four months in which to report, following long delays, I might add, up to that point. As that four-month period expired almost a week ago, can the Minister advise the Senate whether he has received the IAC's report on this matter? Can he further inform the Senate when he expects to be able to announce the Government's decision as to the recommendations of the IAC in this inquiry?

—The IAC report on PVC was received five days ago, in the time stated under the terms of reference. I have received it; I have not yet studied it. But in view of the interest of Senator Evans and other interests outside this Parliament, I will be taking particular care to see that the Government's response to the report is expedited as much as possible. —Has the Minister for Social Security seen the social security benefits information presently being shown on the multicultural television channel? As social security benefit leaflets do not always reach the people who most need the information they contain, would it be possible for all social security benefits information to be similarly screened on other television channels in all States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the advertisements which are being shown on the multicultural television channel. I saw them before they were shown. I think all senators who have seen them will believe they are very good and a very effective means of reaching the important group of people in the community who may require social security benefits. Certainly, I believe that television and radio are more effective than the method we use at the moment to distribute information about social security; that is, the traditional pamphlets which are issued, although I think there is a place for them, too.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the problems with producing television advertisements of this type throughout the country is their very high cost. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that required art materials for tertiary fine arts students can cost between $1,500 and $2,000 per year and that this expense causes great hardship for students on tertiary education assistance scheme allowances? Can consideration be given to exempting art supplies required by full time fine arts students from sales tax as occurs for essential equipment needed in other tertiary courses?

—I will pass on that request to the Treasurer for comment. I do not think I can do other than that at this stage because I have no idea of the revenue implications of acceding to the request which Senator Watson has put forward or, indeed, of even the rate of sales tax which applies to the supplies used by fine arts students to which he referred. I will refer the question to the Treasurer and provide a response as soon as I am able.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It relates to the latest employment figures released last week. In view of the large surge in employment during September, does the Minister believe that the Government's objective in respect of employment generation will now be achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have some figures on the question that Senator Foreman has asked. Several comments could and should be made about the September employment figures. One is that, in seasonally adjusted terms, they rose by more than 50,000 on the figures for the previous month. In actual terms they increased by closer to 120,000 month on month. In seasonally adjusted terms, the level of employment is now, in round figures, 52,000 higher than it was in March when the Government took office. In round figures it is 80,000 above what it was at the low point of April.

ANSWER.PARA: In spite of that very substantial increase in employment during September as against August, April or March, when the Government took office, the unemployment rate rose-the rate being the ratio between those people who are classified as being in the work force and those who are actually employed. The reason for the apparent or superficial inconsistency between a rise in the unemployment rate at the same time as an actual increase of around 120,000 in recorded employment in September as against August is that the participation rate increased substantially in that month-the participation rate being that proportion of the adult population which is recorded as being in the work force. In the same month the participation rate increased by 0.5 per cent. I do not want to be held to be certain of these figures because I do not have them with me but I think it increased from 60.3 per cent to 60.8 per cent. Anyway, the increase in the participation rate was 0.5 per cent, which is a very substantial increase at any time, even in absolute terms, and in one month it is an extraordinarily high rise.

Some statistical quirks could be involved but an increase in the participation rate of that magnitude in one month, should that trend be confirmed in subsequent months, is certainly a clear demonstration that, firstly, the Government's expectations of economic recovery are being realised and its policies are being successful, and, secondly, they are being perceived to be successful because more people are now making applications to get into the work force because they believe that there is a significantly better chance of obtaining employment than there was at the low point of a few months ago. That is an apparent expectation in the public which is, of course, supported by the very large increase in recorded employment during September as against August.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the Middle East policy statement released by the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs on 30 September 1983, and in particular to the Government's decision that it would consider allowing an Arab League office to open in Australia and permit unofficial contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organisation at ambassadorial level. While the Government has given an assurance that no PLO member or representative will be appointed to or employed at any such Arab League office, I ask the Minister: First, is it not a fact that the Jewish community in Australia is still profoundly concerned about the statement and has expressed reservations about aspects of the Government's policy? Secondly, how can the Government be certain that any such office will have no PLO members among its ranks? Thirdly, what action will be taken by the Government to ensure that Arab League offices do not act as a vehicle for promoting PLO activities and that they do not engage in any trade boycott activities directed against companies and individuals trading or wishing to trade with Israel? Fourthly, will he assure the Senate that the Government will not deviate from Australia's long-standing tradition of friendship towards and strong support for Israel against those seeking to isolate and undermine her?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Missen has said, the Government announced that it would consider sympathetically an application to establish Arab League representation in Australia. At the same time the Minister announced that the Government would insist that no PLO member or representative be employed at any such place. I remind honourable senators that the Arab League has information offices in the United Kingdom and the United States, and has had for some time. I am equally aware of the concern of some members of the Australian Jewish community in this regard, because of the conflict in the Middle East. However, the Government believes that it should talk to both sides in that dispute. The Arab League offices in the United Kingdom, the United States and other countries have been a means by which information can be passed on and representatives of this important group in the Middle East can put their views.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been no indication, nor is there any justification for what I thought was an imputation in Senator Missen's question, that this Government would cease to have friendly relationships with Israel, particularly in light of the fact that a former Leader of the Australian Labor Party in this country took part in international forums in the formation of Israel. What the Government seeks to do is to talk to the Arab countries and to Israel to ensure that we and the people of Australia have a balanced view. It may be that the office of the Arab League, without taking any part in any controversial international activities, is the best way to provide representation in a balanced way in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has not answered the substance of my question, which was this: How will the Government ensure that there will not be a PLO representative in such an office and how will it ensure that that person will not be promoting boycotts of Australian firms' activities with Israel, which has happened in Great Britain, the United States and elsewhere?

—First of all, I will seek further details on that matter. Of course, before any foreign national will be allowed to come into the country to take up a position in an Arab League office, he will need a visa and he will need to be investigated. I dare say that through this method of screening PLO representatives will be identified. Secondly, quite clearly, the establishment of such an office will involve conditions and I do not believe that the Government would favour the office of such an organisation indulging in activities such as banning and putting Australian firms under black bans. However, I will seek further details from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and obtain a more detailed answer for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEATH OF PRIME MINISTER OF GRENADA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the murder of the Prime Minister of Grenada, Mr Maurice Bishop, and ask: Is the Minister able to give any details to the Senate concerning his death especially as recently the United States of America had accused Mr Bishop of being pro-Cuban, yet it appears from news reports that he was murdered by pro-Cuban elements in Grenada?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the attempt which was made earlier this week to depose Maurice Bishop, the Prime Minister of Grenada and the subsequent events which led to his death and the death of some of his close supporters. However, the full circumstances of what happened are not known to the Government as yet although we have seen the news reports that Senator Sibraa has undoubtedly seen. The Government certainly regrets that a Commonwealth Prime Minister, who obviously enjoyed strong support amongst the people of Grenada, has been killed in these circumstances. Mr Bishop was known to a number of Australians, including Senator Sibraa I believe, through the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting. I knew him for many years as we were both delegates for many years to the Socialist International. The Government and I hope that the current crisis will be resolved in a way which meets the needs and wishes of the people of Grenada on the basis of an open society and on the basis of democratic institutions.

ANSWER.PARA: It is of great regret to me that Maurice Bishop should have died in this way. It is very sad that he died in the same way as his father died some 10 or 12 years ago. In my position as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs I would prefer not to comment on Senator Sibraa's remarks concerning whether or not the people who have overthrown and killed Maurice Bishop are pro- Cuban and the influence that the United States may have had on that. I will seek further information from the Minister for Foreign Affairs who I am sure will make a more detailed comment in the near future.
