As the Secretary to the Department of Aviation has today advised the fire fighters union that fire fighting services at Wynyard Airport will be withdrawn by the end of this financal year, will the Minister seek to have the question reviewed bearing in mind that Wynyard Airport is, I believe, thirteenth in Australia in aircraft movements and that the service is manned by seven fire fighters and two maintenance men?

—I am aware of Senator Archer's concern and the concern of people who use Wynyard Airport about the Minister's announcement, although I am equally aware that, for many years, this action has been likely. I have no actual details on hand concerning the matter. I assure Senator Archer that I will seek such details from the Minister I am representing at the moment, and get that information for him.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of Labor governments to keep their promises to the Australian people.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first time that the Senate has debated the general proposition that this Hawke-led Government has broken the many promises it made to the people of Australia. I am quite sure that it is not the last time we will be debating this subject because it is becoming increasingly apparent that the word of this government is not worth the paper it is written on or the recording through which it is delivered. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party has invented a new approach to government and to gaining government, which approach involves being absolutely careless about what is promised to the Australian people. The important thing is to gain office, and then not to worry too much about it afterwards. In earlier debates on this subject we have had a fairly standard response from the Government. The Government has said: 'Well, of course, we came and we found a deficit which we did not expect. Therefore, all promises are off' . That is no doubt an answer we will hear again today. Indeed, Senator Robert Ray is nodding.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I start by pointing out that there are promises which do not involve expenditure. Statements were made which do not involve the expenditure of taxpayers' money and which have been brutally ignored by the Government because its internal circumstances have changed. I draw the attention of the Senate to the extraordinary failure of the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Hawke, to live up to the statements he has made about what the Labor Government will do with respect to uranium. This is a classic illustration of using words in such a way that they have no meaning at all. Let us look at what the Prime Minister has had to say about uranium over the last month or two and then let us look at where we are today. This sequence of events bears out the great propensity of the Prime Minister to say whatever his audience wants to hear and to temper and colour his remarks by the shape of his audience.

The Prime Minister was very clear on this subject. At the beginning of September he attended a very successful lunch for the launching of the Business Council of Australia. That was a collection of some of Australia's top businessmen. It was the launching of a new organisation which was intended to give the business sector a more unified voice. The Prime Minister made himself very popular at that gathering by being very direct and clear on the subject of uranium. The Prime Minister said:
. . . as far as our government is concerned, the Federal Government and the Government of South Australia, the Roxby development is going ahead and nothing is going to stop that.

That is what Mr Hawke promised the business leaders of Australia just a couple of months ago. About a week later he gave a long interview which was recorded in Business Review Weekly. No doubt he had his mind on the same audience at that time. Mr Hawke said:
And indeed, of course, when you talk in quantity--
he was talking there of uranium-
terms about the daddy of them all-Roxby-it is covered.

Mr Hawke was saying at that stage that Roxby was covered by the Federal policy. There could be no clearer statement of the Government's position and intention than that. We have since seen a series of half-hearted statements by the Prime Minister when he was speaking to his supporters, if that is what they are called , in the Caucus. His expressions in the Parliament have been quite different. He has been extremely doubtful; he was prepared to say that the matter is subject to review. But when he went to my State of Western Australia, where there is a fair interest in mining and where people would like to see some movement on the Yeelirrie deposit, for example, he became forthright again. The Prime Minister promised much but, of course, is delivering nothing. He made quite a clear statement on radio in Western Australia. He said that as far as Roxby was concerned there was no problem under the present policy of the Government. He said:
The policy of the South Australian Labor Party is for the development of Roxby Downs and that, of course, is totally consistent with the Federal policy.

I will be interested to see whether there is any firm and ringing affirmation of that view in the Senate this afternoon. Are spokesmen for the Government prepared to say that that statement, that promise, that clear statement of the position of the Government is still the clear position of the Government? Or is it true, as is recorded in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, that the Prime Minister has retreated on the subject of uranium and that, under the urging of people like Senator Button, who is of course very influential on him, he has had to agree that the matter should be sent to a committee of inquiry for six months ?

The importance of this example is that it is in no way related to the budgetary position of the Government. There is no suggestion that the Government is having to temper its uranium policy because it believes that the Opposition has left it with a difficult budgetary situation. The fact is that the Government has said one thing but is doing another. In particular, the Prime Minister has said one thing and is doing another. I make it quite clear that the matters I refer to will not in any sense comprise a complete catalogue of the broken promises of the Hawke Government; to do that would take virtually the whole of today and, no doubt, most of tomorrow.

I should like to draw attention to what I see as some of the very significant areas in which the Government can be seen to have broken its promises to the Australian people-promises which were made as recently as last February and which were the cause of the Government's election to office. I suppose the most central breach of faith by the Hawke Government concerns employment and economic policy. I shall quote some of the words in Mr Hawke's policy speech which was delivered on 16 February. These words struck a very responsive chord in the hearts of the people of Australia who were concerned about the issue of unemployment. Mr Hawke said:
There are tremendous issues involved in this historic election on 5 March-first and foremost, the right of all Australians to a job . . .
I repeat:
. . . the right of all Australians to a job.
A little later he went on to say:
For the sake of the 1 million and more Australians who face unemployment unless there is a change, those policies--
that is, the economic policies of the previous Government-
must be changed . . . by the Australian Labor Government after 5 March.

Does anyone seriously claim that Mr Hawke is trying to live up to those words or that he has delivered what he promised? I suggest that the simple test is to look at the extraordinary difference between the approach advocated by the Victorian Government under Mr Cain and the approach advocated by the Prime Minister now that he is in government. Now that he is in government the Prime Minister does not talk about the right of all Australians to a job; he talks about kibbutzim. He thinks that kibbutzim are perhaps the answer. He says: 'Let us put some young people into a kibbutz'. He resurrected his marvellous suggestion of 1979. He and Mr Willis came forward and quite clearly said: 'There will not be a job for all Australians; there is no right for all Australians to have a job'.

He went to Perth and gave the Curtin Memorial Lecture under the mantle of his idol, and he made it quite clear that we can forget the idea of all Australians having a job; that is of the past. I believe that any person most friendly to the Hawke Government would have to admit that what it said before the election- the promise it held out to the people of Australia before the election, the whole basis on which it went to the people of Australia-has been subverted by a change of mind. The Government thought it was a good idea at the time, but it has now changed its mind. I think most people thought the Government would embrace the economic policies developed in Victoria by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research and others. Those economic policies have been deserted by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you supporting what the Victorian Government is doing?

—I suggest that the honourable senator read some of the comments of Kenneth Davidson in the Age if he wants a more impartial observer's comment on that matter. The fact is that the Hawke Government has turned its back on what it promised the people of Australia in that fundamental area of employment. The unemployment rate for young people is now 27.5 per cent. Something like one in four young Australians are without a job. I do not pretend that is a new problem, it just happens to be an increasing problem. What is the Government doing about that? As I said, it is promising perhaps some kibbutzim to do something about it. It is totally ignoring some of the issues of substance such as the report by the Bureau of Labour Market Research which did a study on youth unemployment and which suggests that young people's wages are one part of the problem. They are too high and are pricing young people out of work. The Government shows no inclination to tackle or examine that sort of problem. No, Mr Hawke talks about kibbutzim. What does Mr Dolan, that great friend of the Government, that party to the accord, think about what the Government is doing about that particular problem? Mr Dolan on 17 October is quoted as calling the Government's programs 'a waste of money and not very well thought out'. Mr Dolan is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Even if it had meant blowing out the deficit to an even greater extent, that deficit would have been overcome simply by the fact that people were employed . . .
Youth employment projects 'only provided three to six months' work, anyway, and wouldn't eventually contribute a great deal'.
'I have told my parliamentary colleagues I am not terribly enamoured with some of the schemes that have been embarked upon . . .
He was speaking to the New South Wales Young Labour Council. He stated:

I don't claim to be an economist, but simple arithmetic shows if you can get people back into employment they don't need to be recipients of unemployment benefits and they are contributors so far as tax is concerned.

We will hear speeches which will justify the Government's position from the members of the Government, but the fact remains that when they were in Opposition, when they were seeking election from the people of Australia, they would have denied any suggestion that they would tolerate the position they are tolerating now. They would have denied any suggestion that they would pursue the policies they are pursuing now. I believe that they are damned in particular for their cavalier approach to the statements that they made before the election with respect to employment and economic policy as against the position that they have adopted now. Many other areas are of concern to the Australian people. Let us look at something else Mr Hawke said on 16 February. Referring to the taxation promises-this is from his policy speech delivered to the Australian people, the inducement that he held out for them to vote for him-Mr Hawke said:
Its key elements include immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australian taxpayers.

What a farce. What a joke. Of course, there are no reductions in tax and we have instead a series of excuses. We had a promise from the Government that it would not change the tax on lump sum superannuation payments. The Prime Minister made a commitment, I think again to his friends in the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, that the Federal Government would not increase the tax on lump sum superannuation payments. The Government very quickly broke that promise to its closest supporters in the trade union movement. It promised in that same Budget speech to lift the tax threshold for pensioners to $5,893-it did not do that. It promised not to means test the over-70s pension and not to introduce an assets test. We know what it has done with those promises. The Government has produced reasons, but the reasons were known to it at the time the promises were made. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) was the shadow spokesman for social security for seven years. He is no novice at these promises. He worked very hard, he knew the Department, and he knew the economic arguments. He made promises and his Government made promises which they have simply broken. They were not carelessly made, they were made after most careful consideration and study.

The Government promised to maintain for the home buyers of Australia the home loan interest rebate and it scrapped that; it promised to remove the sales tax on retreaded tyres, it scrapped that promise; it promised to reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre-that promise became inoperative; it promised that it would reduce the price of petrol and instead increased the excise and indexed it so that petrol will go up every six months. There are a whole range of areas where its promises are simply lying on the ground; they have been totally ignored. I hope the lesson which the people of Australia will learn is that the Australian Labor Party pattern now is to promise much to do whatever is needed to get into government and none of it matters once it is elected.

The Government promised to keep the health insurance rebate until the introduction of Medicare; that was abolished even though Medicare has not been introduced. It promised to abolish the pharmaceutical declaration form that was worrying pensioners, a form which we introduced and which Labor said was a dreadful thing to have done. Instead, it kept the form and simply amended it. It promised to reduce the charges for private patients in public hospitals to $60 a day; it has not done that. One can go on. Labor's promise with respect to the Darwin railway is another example. It made it quite clear that it was committed to a commitment of the previous Government and, of course, as soon as it came to office it varied that in the mini-Budget by putting an obligation on the Northern Territory to contribute in a way which it knew was impractical, which it knew was impossible and which meant that that promise was effectively nullified.

There is no sign in anything that has been said in the Senate, by the Prime Minister or any of his Ministers that they regard the breaking of those promises as in any sense significant. They believe that they are entitled to do whatever they like according to the facts of the moment, and their words are utterly irrelevant. It would be less serious if it were not a standard pattern as to what is occurring around Australia. We have seen a number of Labor governments elected in the last year, and in each case the pattern is the same.

I wish in the limited time available to me to make some reference to what was promised in my own State of Western Australia by the Labor Party in January and February when it was running for election in that State. It promised that there would be no increases in government charges during the wages pause. Labor's promises were not made softly; they were not made quietly in the privacy of party councils. No, the Labor Party advertised extensively in the media in Western Australia. It said that it was unfair to have a wage freeze without a price freeze. It said: 'A wage freeze without a price freeze won't work'. Over the photograph of Brian Burke, now the Premier of Western Australia, was listed a series of promises about what Labor would do for the duration of the wage freeze. Labor was going to be fair to the people of Western Australia by ensuring that, while their wages were frozen, there would be no increases in water rates, electricity charges, third party motor insurance, land tax, stamp duty, bus and train fares, rail freight charges, irrigation charges and the State petrol tax. They were the promises of the Burke Opposition in January and February this year. Those promises were made and they were broken one after the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Chaney, I hesitate to interrupt you-
—I wish you would not, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—I do so only because I am bound to. Your motion mentioned the failure of Labor governments to keep their promises to the Australian people.
—Labor governments- plural.

—If Senator Walters wants to waste the Leader of the Opposition's time, she may do so. Senator Chaney, one of the basic rules in this chamber is that the subject matter of a debate on a matter of urgency or a matter of public importance must be on some subject falling within ministerial responsibility. I ask you to tie your remarks to some ministerial responsibility .

—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President. The fact of the matter is that the Labor governments of the States are tightly tied to the financial arrangements they have with the Commonwealth. One cannot separate the arrangements of the States from the arrangements of the Commonwealth, as you will find at the Premiers Conference and other interstate and Commonwealth-State meetings. Let me finish by pointing out that the whole series of promises made by Western Australian Labor, just as firm as the promises made by Mr Hawke on behalf of Federal Labor, have been absolutely cast aside. In Western Australia, water rates have gone up by 16 per cent; electricity charges are up by 15 per cent; bus and train fares are up by one-third; and petrol taxes are up by 13 1/2 per cent. All this took place during the currency of the wage freeze which was urged successfully upon the State government by the Federal Government, if I may establish yet another connection. During the period when the Labor Party in Western Australia promised there would be a freeze, it pursued increases in charges in almost every area. There was a blatant breaking of those election promises. Country sewerage charges went up by 20 per cent, country drainage charges by 18 per cent and State Housing Commission rents by 10 per cent. All of these increases occurred during the wage freeze which the then Federal Government had promoted and which the Labor Party had, of course, opposed. The Labor Party broke those promises without any backward glance.

SPEECH.PARA: The relevance of this debate today is the fact that Labor will go on making those promises. It will go on making statements about charges, about taxes and about all the things that it will do. We have had ample evidence, over recent months, at the Federal and the State level, that those promises mean nothing. In Western Australia charges and taxes have gone up, all in clear breach of the undertakings of the Labor Party before the election. The politics of this country will suffer if promises are so glibly cast aside in circumstances in which the Government cannot point to changes being forced upon it. The fact is that the promises are made without any concern as to their reality or substance and without any concern that those promises should be kept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we could be discussing some important legislation. We could be discussing the Sex Discrimination Bill. The reason we are sitting on Fridays is, in fact, to allow us to discuss important legislation such as that and to deal with Budget legislation. However, we know that those opposite do not like to sit on Fridays. They do not consider that they were elected to sit in this Parliament and deal with the sort of legislation that is coming up. So what we are looking at is, in fact, a time wasting exercise. To indulge in that the Opposition had to cast around and look for what it thought would be a useful matter of public importance. One would have thought from the way Senator Chaney advanced to the table and indulged in the sort of bluster in which he indulged that he had the Government on the run and that he had us in some difficulty. One would have thought that the people in this community were dissatisfied with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I would like to point out to Senator Chaney is that according to the Morgan gallup poll in this week's Bulletin that is not the fact. In fact, in the Morgan gallup poll we have the extraordinary situation where the Prime Minister of this Government, Mr Hawke, has been approved by over 70 per cent of the people of this country. In a competition between the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) we find that over 60 per cent of people believe that the Prime Minister would do the best job and only 20 per cent of people believe that the Leader of the Opposition would do a good job. In fact, this Government which Senator Chaney has castigated in the way he has is three points up on the election result in March which was one of the greatest reversals of electoral fortunes in the history of this country. This is one of the greatest time wasting episodes ever indulged in in the Senate. If ever an empty matter was raised by the Opposition this is it. Poor old Senator Chaney had to be the poor bloke who had to stand in this chamber and front the people of this country with something like this.

This matter of public importance is, in fact, coming from the very people who led this country to economic chaos and to unemployment on a scale that had not been seen since the Depression of the 1930s. Members of the Opposition have the gall to bleat about our policies and our performance after a mere eight months of government. The policies of this Government are directed at turning around the lack of economic confidence in the business world-indeed, they are doing that-the lack of confidence in the housing industry and, in fact, the lack of confidence of the public which existed when the previous Government was in power . They are policies directed at turning around the shoddy ethos of the conservatives opposite whose policies and inaction allowed tax frauds and cheats to prosper while the burden was pushed on to pay as you earn taxpayers in this country, on to pensioners and most of all-I say most of all particularly in view of Senator Chaney's words-on to the unemployed. The conservatives opposite sought to be the ultimate of the granite-hearted realists that they claimed they were. They had Liberal Party opinion polls done to show who was expendable in vote terms and not what the issues were. It was bad luck for the people who did not show up as being crucial to their votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is unemployment going up?

—Let us deal with that in a moment. The honourable senator will get his in the end. Of course, the Fraser Government did not take too many risks at election time. That is the area where we can really talk about broken promises. The previous Government made promises which it knew it had no intention of keeping. Because it did that consistently we could have a bonfire of the lists of promises which were broken a few months after those promises were voted on in the election in this country. Let us deal with the first and most famous of those promises. One of the most cynical of the promises ever made in this community was the Fraser promise of 1975. Members on the front bench opposite were part of those most reprehensible tactics on 11 November 1975. They were leading the applause during the policy speech in that election campaign when the most cynical and unforgettable line ever was uttered: 'We will maintain Medibank'.

SPEECH.PARA: The former Government, spent a fortune of taxpayers' money and this community's money dismantling Medibank, beginning six months after it took office. But because it did not know what it was about and because it did not know where to go, it changed the system on a yearly basis, depending on whether the advice was coming from the Prime Minister, the Treasury, the Department of Health, the Liberal Party Secretariat, the voluntary health funds or the medical profession. Nothing was too much trouble for a government hell-bent on destroying the simplest and the most secure health arrangements this country had ever had. Nothing was too much trouble to erase the constructive achievements of the first Labor Government in 23 years. Yet that promise was always in the background: 'We will maintain Medibank'. The only factor that counted with the miserable Government of those seven years was to trade off the Government's liability for the health care of the community against the doctrinaire policy of throwing health care back to the private interests. It was the sink or swim mentality and I cannot think of any time when the Government of which front bench Opposition members were members showed any concern or any understanding for the people who were going under at that time. All that time, as Senator Chaney said, I was the Opposition spokesman on health in this place. All that time, year after year I debated the pathetic attempts to introduce a sensible and sane health care system in this country. All that time we remembered the words 'We will maintain Medibank'. Only for that reason, if for no other reason, the Government that existed from 1975 to 1983 will go down in history as the least respected, the least competent and the least sympathetic government in this country's history. Those Ministers who were not corrupt themselves were preoccupied with protecting the corruption of others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The suggestion that Ministers were corrupt is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.

—In answer to that point of order, Mr Deputy President, I point out that it was ruled persistently, when we were in Opposition, that unless one directly referred to an individual one could say what one liked. Senator Sir John Carrick in this place persistently and collectively blackguarded members of the former Opposition and we were told that that was within the Standing Orders, that only when individuals were mentioned was it outside the Standing Orders. I mentioned no individual.

—On the point of order, Senator Grimes referred to certain Ministers as corrupt and the rest as protecting them. He therefore included all Ministers. By including all Ministers he transgressed standing order 418. I therefore ask him to withdraw.

—I withdraw because I do not wish attention to be diverted from this debate. I do not wish to divert attention from the incompetence of those who were previously in government in the way in which they covered their incompetence by blaming what they saw as a series of villains. The former Government, of which Senator Chaney was a member, deliberately created an army of unemployed by its contractionary economic policies and it then blamed the schools for not educating pupils in the right way to get jobs. The former Government blamed the unions, it blamed the media, it blamed the European Economic Community, it blamed the economic recession, it blamed the public for not spending but most obscene of all, it blamed the unemployed for not being able to find work. Not once did the former Government blame itself. Let me remind Senator Chaney of the charming phraseology of his Leader in his election speech of 1975:

SPEECH.PARA: We will not use the earning of Australia's families to finance Gold Coast holidays for those who don't want to work.

That is wonderful, emotive stuff for the wealthy supporters of Fraserism who could never understand that for every unemployed person who lived in that area there were thousands in the western suburbs of Sydney and in Melbourne, Wollongong, Newcastle and country areas who could not find work either. Unemployment was and is endemic because of the wreckage of Fraser policies and will remain so until this Government can generate long term confidence in the business and construction world and retain the trust of the union movement and the public.

The trauma of unemployment has not brought Gold Coast holidays to the unemployed. It has brought in its train appalling social consequences. Health problems are greater amongst the unemployed. The risk of family breakdown is considerably higher. An unemployed breadwinner cannot easily cope with his or her failure to find or retain a job. His or her spouse cannot cope with the rage of frustration and helplessness. Young people are driven from home because of the pressures of their parents or because parents cannot understand the failure of their children to get a job. They do not get to the Gold Coast; they are lucky to find the fares to get to work. The miserable Opposition takes exception to them doing as other Australians do, and that is having a bit of time off. With due respect, Senator Chaney and his mean-spirited team believe that the place of the unemployed is in the queue at the soup kitchen, and preferably wearing rags.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Does Senator Chaney want to be reminded of his discredited leader's promise? It was:

SPEECH.PARA: We will be generous to those who can't get a job and want to work.

The so-called generous attitude was exemplified by the former Minister for Social Security, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, whose first Press release as a Minister for Social Security was a statement entitled 'Move to Stop Dole Cheats' . The first action, statement No. 1 from the then new Minister for Social Security, was: 'Move to Stop Dole Cheats'. That was the way in which members of the former Government started to regard the unemployed and that was the way in which they continued to do so. If they were ever generous, no one in the country detected it. They froze the rate of benefit for the single unemployed in their first Budget after the 1977 election. They never explained it. They never talked about it before the election. They never apologised about it.

They not only punished the unemployed financially for not being able to find a job which was never there; they tightened the unemployment benefit guidelines year after year in a way which always hurt unemployed families. Wealthy Liberals who did not give a damn, because there was plenty of work at that time for them and their unemployed children, cheered as unemployed school leavers were deprived of money, as the least literate and the least confident unemployed were faced with bureaucratic hurdles that they could not hope to master. They were generous in their contempt for the unemployed, and that is all that they were generous in.

When Mr Fraser was Opposition spokesman on employment in 1974, he promised to take unemployment benefits to the level of the minimum wage if the unemployment level exceeded 250,000. He never intended to do that, just as the present Opposition never intends to carry out the promises that it is making now, even at this early stage in opposition. I suggest that the present floundering Leader of the Opposition, when he attempted the other day to censure this Government for the rate of unemployment today, was treated with contempt by the community and the Press because it was an example of hypocrisy, and everyone knows that it was an example of hypocrisy. Members of the Opposition seem to be having problems with their short term and long term memories. I remind them that when we left Government in November 1975 there were 265,000 unemployed, and we were not at all happy about that, any more than we are happy about the present situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many were there when you went into government?

—When the Fraser Government was kicked out, there were 636,000 unemployed. That Government had managed to more than double that number, and members of the Opposition have the gall to come into this place, after we have been in government for eight months, and say that we have not done enough about unemployment. In their rush to be seen to be concerned about the unemployed, after years of pushing them into demoralisation, this Opposition acts as though the whole problem materialised in the last six or eight months. I make the point again: The previous Government's policies added 371,000 more to the official number of unemployed and forced them into humiliation and into debt. In the case of the young unemployed, that benefit stayed at $36 a week while wages, salaries and even pensions rose. Their misery was often compounded by homelessness and brutalisation which made them prey to every social evil in the country. All this from the followers of the man who said in his 1975 policy speech:

SPEECH.PARA: We have placed jobs first. We have placed Australia first.
I suggest that the crocodile tears of the Leader of the Opposition in this place today are a disgrace.

I move to another promise that the same Opposition front benchers vigorously applauded in 1975 and then ignored, the promise that the real value of pensions would be preserved. We have two ex-Ministers for Social Security in the chamber this afternoon. When the Whitlam Government took power in 1972 the standard rate of pension was 19 per cent of average weekly earnings. It rose to in excess of 24 per cent of average weekly earnings. At that time, because of the coalition's neglect, we believed it was proper to give major increases to pensioners and beneficiaries, and the increase in the pension rate was in fact almost twice the rate of inflation at that time.

Honourable senators opposite clearly do not have that same commitment to the disadvantaged because the pension rate in relation to average weekly earnings had dropped to 22 per cent of average weekly earnings when the electorate rejected the Fraser Government. It is our intention and our promise to take the standard rate of pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, and we promise to do this in the first three years of government. We will do this. It does no good for honourable senators opposite to claim that we promised any more than that because even before we knew of the deception of the previous Prime Minister and the deception of the discredited former Treasurer in respect of the deficit figures, we knew that it would not be easy just to walk in and raise pensions in this way.

In our first Budget we have made progress in areas neglected by the previous Government. We have introduced a special zone allowance for pensioners in Zone A , who have been long recognised as being disadvantaged in this country. This allowance will benefit about 10,000 pensioners living in Queensland. We have increased the unemployment benefit and indexed the single unemployment benefit as first steps in getting these benefits back to the standard that applied in 1978.

We have promised to revive the economy. Mr Fraser, of course, promised to do that. In November 1975 he said that a growth rate of 6 per cent to 7 per cent would be 'quite feasible in recovering from the slack under Labor' and 'would enable us to halve the deficit'. In fact, gross domestic product growth during the Fraser years was only 2 1/2 per cent per annum. In the last year of that Government GDP took a nose dive, with the June quarter GDP falling 2.3 per cent, to be 3.9 per cent lower than in the June quarter of 1982 and 4.6 per cent below the peak reached in the September quarter of 1981. The worst economic recession in 50 years was not enough to stop Mr Fraser proclaiming on 14 February 1982:
Australia's position in relation to economic management is the envy of many other countries.

In fact, Australia's inflation, growth and unemployment performance over the Fraser years were significantly worse than the average for all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, despite our rich natural resources and relative immunity from successive oil shocks. We sat in this chamber and listened to the then Leader of the Government, Senator Sir John Carrick, tell us about the wonders that were going to occur from the Rundle scheme, talking up Rundle shares, as we said he was doing all along, talking up a boom. Where is that boom now? Where was the evidence that the boom was ever going to come? When people such as Senator Walsh and I suggested that this was what he was about, we were told that we were hampering the Government's effort for recovery.

One could go on all afternoon, as Senator Chaney suggested he could, about the incredible number of promises made by the previous Government in the fields of health, social security, economic development, and minerals and energy. These promises were not carried out. That Government failed. The best example of how that Government failed can be seen in the present numbers in the House of Representatives, in the polls that were published this week, and in the position of some of the leaders who made those promises such as Senator Sir John Carrick and others, who are now sitting on the back bench in the Senate. There they will stay because they are the past masters of broken promises. They are the people who could not retain the faith of the people. We will retain that faith. We will govern this country and lead it back to progress. We will not be stopped by stupid and silly matters of public importance like this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — This afternoon we are discussing a matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of Labor governments to keep their promises to the Australian people.

In every election, no matter what party is presenting its policies, promises are always made. In the light of day when that party gets into power, I guess there is general recognition that some of those policies cannot be fulfilled. However, in this instance we have seen a complete election manifesto repudiated once the party got into government. The whole manifesto was repudiated, except one promise-of course, that was Medicare, and who needs that. One has only to look at the record that Medibank provided of increased costs to the people of Australia in the three years that the Labor Government was in power from 1972 to 1975 to realise what a disaster it was then, as, of course, Medicare will ultimately be. Never before has a complete manifesto been so easily repudiated in such a short time. As a matter of fact, to misquote a leading world statesman , 'Never in the field of Australian politics has so much been promised to so many who ultimately received so little'. It is quite interesting that at this time there is an election campaign going on in my home State.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would never know it.

—No, one would never know it, but it will all be over next week and everything will return to normal. It is quite interesting to read the remarks of the Labor leader before the 5 March Federal election and those of the Queensland Leader of the Opposition before the current State election. I quote Mr Hawke:

SPEECH.PARA: We offer no miracles. We offer no overnight solutions for the immediate problems we face or the deep-seated problems we must face together.
I believe the Australian people have had enough of election promises made only to be broken. I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.
Mr Wright has said:
I come before you with no grab-bag of campaign promises made only to be broken, no shopping list of uncosted proposals . . .

So it goes on, with very similar words from the two Labor leaders. We have just heard the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) speak and it is interesting that not once did he address himself to the matter before the chamber today. He never mentioned it because, of course, he could not. Everybody knows that and the people of Australia are slowly waking up to it. He has mentioned the popularity of the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as shown in the polls. I, like every boy, learnt very early in life that the higher one climbs up a tree the further it is to fall. Of course, that fall will come very shortly and it will be quite calamitous.
Let us look now at some of the promises made. With respect to taxation, Mr Hawke said:
Labor's tax reform program will have these objectives:
to increase the real value of the pay packet and stimulate demand in the economy
to restore equity to the tax system
to redress the tax burden, on the principle of ability to pay
to prevent the erosion of after-tax income by inflation, and so support the prices and incomes policy
to end the loss of untold millions of dollars through the tax evasion and avoidance industry.
Mr Wright says:
Just as the Commonwealth has had wide-ranging reviews of its taxation procedures, a Labor Government will establish a special Commission to review-
I understand that it will be one of about 17 commissions we will have if by some mischance Mr Wright gets into government-
and report on State Revenue, State Taxes and State Charges.
Mr Hawke said:
The major points of Labor's tax reform will be:
a new six step tax scale to restore the progressive nature of the tax system
a lift in the tax threshold to $5,000 which will free tens of thousands of low income earners from all tax
a lift in the tax threshold for pensioners of $4650 to $5893
increases in the spouse rebate and sole parent rebate, resulting in additional tax cuts of $2 a week to families
increases in zone allowances by 25 per cent for taxpayers in remote areas.
Mr Wright says:

Labor will revise the present system of electricity tariffs and ease the burden of electricity costs on householders and business. We propose a major review of State taxes and charges but there are three specific areas where a Labor Government will reduce such costs. Labor will abolish payroll tax for all apprentices. Labor will abolish stamp duty and Labor will not introduce a State Income Tax.

That is similar rhetoric. It is interesting that the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland is going around talking about his costed proposals but he has not costed the so-called reductions that the people might receive if, as I said, by some mischance he gets into power. But how much can we believe? The Prime Minister is in Queensland this day trying to convince Queenslanders that they should vote in the Labor Party because of all the things he has done. What has he done? Certainly he has not done any of the things that he promised. Where is the six-step tax scale? What about the lift in the tax threshold to $5,000; where is that? What about the lift in the tax threshold for pensioners; where is that? What about the increase in the spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate? So it goes on; the list is endless. As I said, the Deputy Leader of the Government in this chamber spoke for twenty minutes and not once did he address himself to the subject before the chamber-the unfilled promises of the Labor Government. Mr Hawke, on the prices and incomes accord, said:
The Government will endeavour to reduce the relative incidence of indirect taxation because of its regressive and inflationary nature.

What hypocrisy! What has happened since then? Not only have excises not been reduced; indeed, they are now indexed. I call it a Gold Lotto budget-in other words, every six months this Labor Government wins the lottery but it is the taxpayers of Australia who are buying the tickets, with monotonous regularity. What hypocrisy! These excises apply to many and various things that affect the everyday lives of people. That is particularly the case with fuel and the extra sales tax which has to be paid on lubricating oils by some people in rural industry. It has a compounding effect right throughout the community, involving people who rely on every mode of transport just to get to and from work and those who rely on transport for goods and services. It goes right down the line; we have a compounding effect right through this country from a government and a Prime Minister who promised that indirect taxation would be reduced.

What about local government? Labor Party policy is to index grants to local government. The coalition Government brought up those grants to 2 per cent of income tax, and the policy of the Labor Party is that it will allocate at least 2 per cent of Federal personal income tax as a general revenue grant to local government, the allocation in any year to be not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation. What happened? In 1982-83 the consumer price index rose by 11.2 per cent and local government's share of personal income tax collections rose by only 8.2 per cent. It is interesting that Mr Wright promised at a local government seminar that there would be an indexed grant of $45m to local government in Queensland-the same words again, the same promises. We can only suppose what the results would be. It is interesting that he said that at a local government seminar and was not quite game to mention it in his speech.

I turn to unemployment. When the present Prime Minister hit the election trail he said: 'This election is about jobs, jobs, jobs'. What an abysmal record the Government has. The present Prime Minister said that 500,000 jobs would be created in three years. Further, he said that an estimated 70,000 new full time jobs would be created for an average duration of six months. Where are those jobs now? Senator Grimes mentioned the unemployment record when Labor left office in 1975. The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, by way of interjection asked: 'What was it when they got into power?' It is very interesting that Senator Grimes did not reply. The Labor Government invented unemployment in Australia in its time in office from 1972 to 1975. When the Whitlam Government took over the unemployment rate was running at about 2.4 per cent or approximately 136,000 people. When it left office in 1975 the rate has reached 5.6 per cent or, in round figures, 328,000 people. The Labor Government invented unemployment in Australia. We had not seen the likes of that for years. In this chamber we have representatives of the great proletariat, supposedly representing the working people, slowly and surely putting more and more of them out of work. So we have reached the situation we are in today. The latest figures on unemployment indicate that the only ray of hope on the horizon is Queensland. Queensland was the only State in which the level of unemployment had gone down. In every other State it had gone up. People should be aware of the fact that page 135 of Budget Paper No. 1-the Government's own statement, with all the rhetoric gone-indicates an expected increase in unemployment of 139,800 people this year. What a betrayal of the Australian people. What a betrayal of the people, with hopes held so high, who put the Government in office.

The Government is a high tax government. Between 1 July 1973 and 30 June 1976, which were basically Labor Budget years, the total income tax take rose by 125 per cent. The total tax take, when one looks at indirect taxation as well as company tax and so on, rose by 99.3 per cent. In that period average weekly earnings rose by only 67 per cent. In the first three years of the Fraser- Anthony Government income tax rose by just 39 per cent, total tax by 38 percent and average weekly earnings by 33 per cent. In other words, the Labor Government lifted taxes three times faster than did the coalition, while lifting earnings only twice as quickly as the coalition. What an horrendous record. Of course, people forgot about it on 5 March, but they are fast being reminded of it. This Government is hypocritical. It stalks around the countryside as if it were the representative of the great proletariat. The Government has betrayed the people abysmally. The record is an indictment against the Government on its mismanagement of this country in such a short time. I suggest that there is a case to answer. I hope that the following speakers in this debate can do better at answering the charges which have been raised by Senator Chaney and me and those which will be raised by Senator Baume, than the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate did. He was not game to address himself to the problem before the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -The matter of public importance that we are discussing this afternoon refers to the failure of Labor governments to keep their promises. One of the Labor governments referred to was the Hawke Labor Government which has been in office since March this year. The Budget brought down in August this year is a sound Budget. Certaily, we would have liked to have done more, but let us remind ourselves of what happened when we were elected in March. The election campaign went through February and early March. We made certain assumptions about what the state of the Department of the Treasury would be when we came to government. When we got here we found that the cupboard was bare. Not only was it bare; it also had a tremendous overdraft. We were facing a deficit of $9.6 billion. When we realised that we had that deficit in front of us we had to tailor our cloth to meet what was there and what we could raise in the first Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not forget that when we made those promises we made them for the first Hawke Labor Government. We did not make them for the first Budget; they were made for a full three years. Is the Opposition trying to indicate that its aim is for this Government to have only a one Budget term such as occurred in 1974 and 1975? If that is its aim it will fail. When it looks back at a full record of the Hawke Government after its three year term it will see the promises that have been implemented. It is folly at this stage to list the promises that we said we would fulfil over a full term of government and say that they have not been fulfilled because we have introduced one Budget.

It is necessary for me to put Senator Chaney's comments made during his speech on this matter of public importance into perspective. In doing so I will first make some comment about the previous Federal Administration and then, to use Senator Chaney's argument, I will make some comments about a State administration. I came to this place early in 1976 after being elected in the December 1975 election. At that stage I was very concerned about the plight of the unemployed as I have always been. It is not necessary to have experienced the frustrations of unemployment to be concerned about the unemployed. But having had that experience one can never lose a compassion towards those who want work and cannot find work.

I do not speak very much of my own family background, but I think it is probably pertinent in this regard. My father was in the building industry. He experienced long periods of unemployment while he was putting me through school. I understood the frustrations of, not only people who were employed, but also of a whole family being unemployed. Later I also experienced periods of unemployment. It was not very nice at the time, but looking back I am glad I did because I understand the frustrations that people have. So it was not unusual for me, when I came to this place, to be concerned about the unemployed then. It was not unusual for me to be concerned during the campaign about what would happen to the unemployed. Thus, when I was elected to this place I waited for the new Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, to fulfil his promise that he would provide jobs for all who wanted to work. Senator Grimes has already spoken about this matter. But let us examine what happened. Year after year from 1975 until now as I sat on the Opposition benches unemployment increased. It increased, despite the promise that there would be jobs for all who wanted to work. When Mr Fraser came into power on 11 November 1975 there were 310,100 people out of work. That represented 5 per cent of the work force. When he left office in March of this year, and the closest figures we can get are for February 1983, that 310,100 had increased to 747,300, which represented 10.7 per cent of the work force.

Lest it be suggested that I am comparing months which are not like, November and February, let us have a look at the seasonally adjusted figures. The seasonally adjusted figures indicate that in November 1975 there were 334,800 people out of work, which represented 5.4 per cent of the work force. In February 1983 that figure had increased to 669,500 or 9.6 per cent. In other words, there was an increase from 5.4 per cent to 9.6 per cent. We are faced this afternoon with arguments about Labor not keeping its promises when we have been in office for only eight months. The former Government was in office for seven years. It said it would provide jobs for all and the number of unemployed increased from 5.4 per cent to 9.6 per cent, if we are using seasonally adjusted figures.

I should like to make some comments about Medibank, which was mentioned earlier . The previous speaker, Senator Collard, used words to this effect: 'Medibank was a disaster from 1972 to 1975'. Let me remind the Senate that Medibank was introduced in the last half of 1975. It took that amount of time for us to gear up to Medibank. It was not even working for six months when the election came around in 1975. But it was popular, even though it had not been working for six months. It was so popular that the then caretaker Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, said: 'We will retain Medibank'. I can remember watching him on television delivering his policy speech. I think one should always watch one's opposition on television. One must know one's enemy. I can remember having watched him on television and he said, 'we will maintain Medibank' and the crowd behind him gave a great big cheer because he knew, and they knew, that Medibank was popular . Maintain Medibank he did, but he retained it in name only.

I can remember, as you can remember, Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure, and as many other people on this side of the chamber can remember, that when we were on the other side of the chamber, year after year after year there was a change to the health insurance system of Australia, and it was not very long before Medibank had gone. Yet the Opposition talks this afternoon about Labor's broken promises. But there were broken promises on that side all throughout that period. I may have made one error. I think that there was one year in those seven when there was not any change and we were most amazed because we kept expecting change year after year because of the pattern that had built up. I am sure that when the three year term of the Hawke Labor Government is concluded and we look back, not on Medibank, as we had at that time, but on Medicare, which we have virtually introduced and which will come into operation on 1 February next year, we will see that it was just as popular or perhaps even more popular than Medibank because it will have been going for so much longer than Medibank was going when the election came around in 1975. It would be a foolish government, a foolish opposition or a foolish party which would say when the next election comes around that it would dismantle Medicare. I am sure that that is the aim of some of the people on the other side. We have heard statements from some of their spokespersons saying that they will dismantle Medicare. But that does not particularly concern me very much, because it will be many years before the Liberal and National Parties get their hands on Medicare.

Using Senator Chaney's example of tying State government expenditure in with Federal government expenditure and the revenue that results from doing so, let me mention some of the promises that have been made in Queensland by the current administration, which will lose its place in history tomorrow.
