SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concern of Australians is with the performance of the Government of the day. They are not concerned with the past, but with what is happening now in Australia. The subject of this matter of public importance is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of Labor governments in Australia to keep their promises.

The proposition I will advance and which I will put to the Senate is that we cannot trust Labor. We are out to sheet home the broken promises. I will cite some of the matters where Labor governments-whether or not the promises have cost money-have moved to break solemn undertakings and promises. If a promise has been broken, it has been broken. It is no good for Senator Colston to say that the promises will be redeemed over three years. Some of them have been dishonoured already and nothing can bring back those promises.

Perhaps it is in order to set out some of the things which this Government has done in a few short months to set aside solemn undertakings to the Australian people. What were some of the promises? I am indebted to my colleague Senator Lewis for preparing a list of some of those promises. The Labor Government promised immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million people, and that has not been honoured. It promised no change in lump sum superannuation payments. It dishonoured that promise. It promised to maintain the home loan interest rebate. It dishonoured that promise and the rebate was abolished. It promised to keep the health insurance rebate until the introduction of Medicare. It dishonoured that promise and the rebate was abolished. We simply cannot trust Labor. It promised that it would not introduce an assets test. It dishonoured that promise and it has announced its intention to introduce a test, the details of which are now being worked out. It promised to abolish the pharmaceutical declaration form. It dishonoured that promise. It promised to maintain drought relief to help recovery. It dishonoured that promise. It promised adequate compensation for Tasmanians in lieu of their dam. It certainly has not yet honoured that promise. We simply cannot trust the Australian Labor Party in government.

It promised to remove the sales tax on retreaded tyres. We heard about that in the Senate recently. That promise has been dishonoured. It promised to reduce the price of petrol by 3c per litre, and that promise has been dishonoured. It promised to reduce charges for private patients in public hospitals by $60 a day , and that has been dishonoured. It promised there would be no more job losses in the steel industry, and that promise has not been kept. We cannot trust Labor Governments. It promised to maintain real funding for local government, and it has dishonoured that promise. It promised to lift the tax threshold for pensioners to $5,000 or $5,893, depending on their circumstances. It has not honoured that promise. It promised-my colleague Senator Messner would know about this-that there would be no tax or excise increase on wines, and it has dishonoured that promise.

Many of those promises were not contigent upon the Budget. They were promises which were made to protect people, and they have been callously and systematically broken during the Government's first short period in office. There are 15 broken promises or assurances to the education communities around Australia, ranging from specific promises in schools, colleges of advanced education and universities, and specific promises to students. Those promises have been dishonoured. The Government promised to create 500,000 new jobs during its first period in government. It has delivered in its first seven months a loss of 68,000 jobs. We now have the lowest participation rate in the work force that we have had for 20 years. It has dropped by two per cent in the first eight months of the Labor Government. Those looking for jobs cannot trust the Labor Government. We have lost our income tax rebate for health insurance, when we were promised that it would remain. We have lost the home deposit assistance scheme. We have lost the housing interest rebate scheme. We have lost our $1,000 dividend rebate. Members of the Defence Force Reserve have lost the tax exemption for the pay they receive for their periodic training. We have lost equality in Federal funding for children in non-government schools as compared with the funding given to government schools.

From all these broken promises we deduce that one cannot trust the Labour Party . One cannot trust the Labor Party in view of the large number of promises which it made before the election as bait to the electors and which have been broken since that time. Many of those promises were not dependent upon the State of the economy. Many of them were not dependent upon the Government's Budget capacity; they were matters of ideology and they were in direct contrast with what was promised before the election.

It is not just the Hawke Government in Canberra which cannot be trusted. In many of the States the governments have the same sorry record. If we look at the complex arrangements which exist between the New South Wales Government and the Federal Government, for the flow of funds, and if we look at the way in which New South Wales comes to the Federal Government for the grants it needs to redeem its promises, what do we find? Before two State elections the New South Wales Government promised to improve education by reducing face to face teaching and by improving library services. Those promises have not been redeemed. We now find the New South Wales Teachers Federation in bitter conflict with the Government of that State. The promise of a second harbour crossing has not been delivered. A ninth lane on Sydney Harbour Bridge to help traffic flow was promised but the promise has not been delivered. A major promise to build a large sports stadium at Homebush that surely would have involved some negotiations with the Commonwealth in order to find the funds-has not been redeemed. A specific promise was given to provide a $15m extension to Sydney Hospital and to retain the hospital. That has not been redeemed. Sydney Hospital has been closed and the $15m was never provided.

The finances of the Cain Government in Victoria are entwined with those of the Federal Government also. The Cain Government made promises which required Federal Government funding by way of grants and loans to make them a reality. What did it promise? It promised not to increase State taxes or charges in any area. In fact, taxes have increased by 40 per cent. It promised to reduce gas prices by 4 per cent. They have increased by about a third. It promised that most electricity users would pay no more than they were paying when the last increase was made by the Government it replaced. In fact the charges have increased by a quarter. It promised to scrap the petrol tax increase which it inherited. In fact, it has increased petrol tax even further-petrol tax is up by 1c a litre. The Cain Government promised to reduce public transport fares. They have actually doubled for some people and are up markedly. The Labor Government in Victoria promised to review all health charges and collecting procedures. It has increased hospital charges by about two-thirds. In Victoria people have found under a Labor Government that they cannot trust the Labor Party. They cannot trust Labor in government. Every time Victorians turn on a tap, a light, a stove or a heater and every time they go to the toilet they are paying tax because of the taxes imposed by the authorities which provide all the services.

In the same way, the South Australian Government, depending as it does, on many States grants, has its funding entwined with that of the Commonwealth. The Labor Party policy speech in South Australia stated:
Unlike the Liberals, we will not allow State charges like transport fares, electricity and hospital charges to be used as a form of back-door taxation.
What did Labor deliver? Do people have any reason to trust Labor as a result of their experience in South Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—No, my colleague Senator Chaney says correctly. There have been substantial increases in over 70 areas of State Government activity. Hospital fees have increased by 20 per cent. Electricity charges and tariffs are up by 12 per cent. The overall average increase in transport costs in South Australia is almost a half. In spite of the pre-election promises of the Labor Party, the facts are that one cannot trust Labor in government in South Australia. One cannot trust Labor in government in Victoria; one cannot trust Labor in government in New South Wales; and one cannot trust Labor in government in Canberra.
—You can trust them to break their promises.

—Senator Chaney says that we can trust the Labor Government to break its promises. That is about all that we can trust it to do. I was attracted by what the Speaker who preceded me in this debate, Senator Colston, said when he drew attention to some of the situations that exist in Queensland and to some of the prospects that lie ahead for Queenslanders. I do not wish to canvass those matters. I merely wish to record for the Senate some of the realities about Queensland today.

SPEECH.PARA: First, Queensland is the State with lower State taxation than any other State in Australia-State taxes are less than $500 a year, compared with higher rates in the other States. It is the State with a growing population. It is the State with less strikes. It is the State with more investment. It is the State with a better record on employment and finding jobs-a record that is in stark contrast with what the Hawke Government has done at the Federal level. It is the State with a better record in job creation. With about one-sixth of the Australian population, Queensland has had only 6 per cent or so of the nation's industrial disputes. It has attracted almost one-fifth of the nation's foreign investment proposals. It has generated about one-fifth of the fixed capital spending and the expected capital spending. It is the national leader in job creation and growth and in fighting unemployment.

The first seven months of the Hawke Labor Government give us examples of the most cynical approach to election undertakings seen from any elected government in the memory of any of us. It is quite clear that the Hawke Government had absolutely no intention of honouring the very many vote buying promises which it made to the Australian people. Let me remind you again, Mr Acting Deputy President, that many of the promises which were broken were not promises that cost money; they were promises that were made to protect things which people had , which they valued and which they did not want to lose. But the promises were broken anyhow once the votes had been obtained and once people had put the Government into power.

Australians just cannot trust the Labor Party. It is clear that the Australian electorate has been conned. It is clear that the unemployed were conned. It is clear that the average wage earner was conned. It is clear that those who were anticipating tax cuts were conned and it is clear that many other members of the community who had their expectations raised during the election campaign have been conned as well. The truth is that the Labor Party is always prepared, in every election campaign, to promise the world in order to win power. It is so anxious for power that it would even abandon its principles and its party platforms, if necessary, in order to offer the most pragmatic program that this country has ever seen. Already its record in government is clear. The litany of dishonoured promises is lengthening every day; it is on the record. My colleague Senator Chaney has demonstrated-Senator Collard has supported him-that the Hawke Labor Government is not a government that can be trusted. Australians cannot trust Labor. They never could and they will never be able to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of Labor governments to keep their promises to the Australian people.

This would truly have become an appropriate matter of public importance if it had simply read: 'The failure of governments to keep their promises to the Australian people'. If ever there were a theme to which the Australian people would warm, it would be that one. I suggest that the matter of public importance brought into this chamber by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, which seeks to restrict the debate to the honesty of Labor governments only, would have been much better received by anybody listening to this debate if it had related to all governments. It is a fact that the Australian people view politicians with the utmost suspicion because of the regularity with which every government tends to make extravagant promises at election time and then finds excuses later not to keep those promises. Trying to assess which promises will be kept and which promises will not be kept has become a national game. Indeed the media have a very pleasant time in trying to assess this from time to time. But it has very little to do with the government of the country. Of course, the basic situation is that any government can be relied upon not to keep its promises when it gets into office. That has been the reason for the tremendous deterioration in respect for the institution of Parliament in the minds of the Australian people, and rightly so.

Why then has this matter of public importance been brought into the Senate today? No doubt it has occurred to listeners that the fact that a State election in Queensland and four State by-elections in New South Wales are to be held tomorrow is not wholly unconnected with it. This then is an electioneering debate, or an attempt is being made to make it one. However, I propose to deal mostly with some real issues that have a direct bearing on this matter of the honesty of governments. Firstly, I do not believe that debates of the nature of this one so far cut much ice with the Australian people. Not unnaturally, they would prefer us to get on with the business of government rather than the innuendo and adversary politicking we have heard over the last several hours. I wonder then why these things continue. Are they just a sheer continuation of bad habits on the part of the perpetrators, who must surely know by now that they are highly counterproductive with the electorate?

Of course, a government may elect not to keep a promise to the people because it feels in its own conscience that it is well intentioned not to do so, because it believes that circumstances have changed in such a way as to make it no longer wise, prudent or necessary to keep that promise. Whatever they may think when they come to office, governments do not necessarily have a monopoly on wisdom. That applies just as much to the present Labor Government as to any other government. Two classic examples come readily to mind. They are issues on which the present Government has made promises and which are very relevant to this debate. Because of that, I propose to look at those two issues at some length in light of the matter we are now considering.

The first issue I wish to discuss is uranium, which was raised earlier in the debate by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). Of course, whether or not we should mine and export uranium is a very complex and important issue. It is a fact that the majority of the Australian people are deeply worried about the morality and wisdom of our country continuing to mine and export uranium. Decent Australians do not like to be involved in a traffic which presents such terrible dangers to the world, not only to our generation but also to our children, our grandchildren and to all generations beyond. How could anyone be happy with an industry which, it is already known, will significantly increase the rate of fatal cancers in future and which, it has been proven by experiments on animals, can cause horrendous and unnatural mutations to innocent human beings even before they are born? Those same decent Australians cannot subscribe to the morality of the drug pedlar now being urged on them by the supporters of the uranium industry. These people say: 'You can get money by selling our uranium. Do not worry about the possible bad effects. If the buyers could not get uranium from us they would get it from someone else.' That is what I mean by the morality of the drug pedlar.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the honourable senator's attention to the subject before the Chair.

—I respect your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. I merely wish to demonstrate that this matter is a matter of some importance in respect of which this Government has not kept its promises to the electorate. The Leader of the Opposition raised this matter at some length earlier in the debate and was permitted to do so. I just bring that point to your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will complete the point I was making, if I may. I worked for a number of years in Thailand and I know, as a result, that we could probably bring to Australia the capital and expertise to establish an industry to grow and export heroin. It would be much more profitable than uranium, and the argument would be: 'Do not worry about the bad effect. If they cannot get this heroin from us they will get it from somebody else'. I suggest that is an analagous situation.

SPEECH.PARA: In this matter of pubic importance we are talking about the Government keeping its promises. Before the election Labor candidates campaigned regularly on the facts I have just mentioned. Of course, that is why I am raising those points in this debate. It was right and proper for them to raise those points concerning uranium, and they did so repeatedly. But it is not right and proper, and never can be, for the Labor Government, having obtained the trust and confidence of the Australian voters over this issue, then to betray them. It betrayed not only the voters but also the world and the future by allowing this thoroughly discredited uneconomic industry to proceed. Admittedly, the Government has not yet taken that decision but there seems to be all the indications that it may well do so.

While the Government is contemplating the promises it made to the electorate it might also face up honestly to the close, growing and immensely dangerous link between the uranium industry and nuclear weapons. That link is now so close that respected commentators have described the nuclear power industry as a means of producing plutonium for bombs with an electric power spin-off. It is a fact that the by-products of nuclear power-houses can be used to produce bombs, and indeed quite recently laser technology has been developed to the point where it can increase the enrichment of ordinary nuclear power-house fuel to make small, dirty A-bombs of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki type.

To avoid these unpleasant facts and to try to justify its position on uranium to the Australian people the Government has sought to hide behind another red herring. It told the Australian people that the synroc process being developed by Professor Ringwood at the Australian National University will solve the problems of nuclear waste. I think we must, in the light of honesty of government, take a careful look at that statement. The facts are, of course, that synroc is a mixture of high level radioactive waste and natural materials such as barium and calcium which has been subjected to high temperatures and pressure to produce a simulated rock which is more stable than the glass which is now being used for radioactive waste storage at high temperatures and which requires a shorter cooling time. However, to achieve this stability and to keep the time in which the synroc needs to be kept under refrigeration to under 100 years, which, after all, is a fairly substantial period, the radioactive waste must be reprocessed to remove the most highly radioactive isotopes, uranium 235 and plutonium 239.

What the Labor Government said to us and to the people of Australia when it sponsored this idea is: 'It is great to have synroc. We are putting money into synroc. You will have a reprocessing industry in Australia and you will have a plutonium economy in which there will be large amounts of reprocessed uranium 235 and plutonium 239 around the community'. There is no avoiding that. If we are to get those things out of the fuel rods we have to reprocess the material here. If we are to use synroc we have to reprocess first. Let us be absolutely clear about that. Indeed, the Government ought to know this. Before it breaks its promises to the Australian people, I refer it to the eminent American journal, Science, of September 1980-some considerable time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a good idea to reprocess it before we put it in synroc, would it not?

—We would have to reprocess it before we put it in synroc. That is just what I have been saying. For that reason alone, of course, it makes synroc an unacceptable option for this country, or indeed for any other. We have the reprocessing chain ahead of us. We have to dispose of the nuclear fuel rods through the reprocessing system before we even get near the synroc system of disposal. The article in Science, of course, casts considerable doubt on the ability to use materials which contain alkali metals or alkaline earths at all. This includes glass and synroc. That article, which is completely authoritive, otherwise the journal of the United States Academy of Sciences would not have published it three years ago, points out:

SPEECH.PARA: Materials containing alkali metals or alkaline earths are sensitized by bombardment with either ions, electrons, or protons to chemical attack by atmospheric moisture.

In other words a large series of investigations will have to be carried out in regard to synroc with radioactive material-if we ever use it-to be sure that over a long period it does not deteriorate, as indeed it has already been shown that glass would do under atmospheric conditions.

I do not know whether the Government will keep its promises to the Australia people in regard to the uranium issue. I sincerely hope it does. I read with great pleasure today reports in both the Melbourne Age and the Sydney Morning Herald that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, has now modified his previous attitude of support for the nuclear industry and the Roxby Downs project in particular. I can understand the pressures on Mr Hawke over this matter, both at home and internationally, because obviously I have been under very much smaller pressures from the highly organised and wealthy lobby, the uranium producers, who are pushing their barrow with great energy at the moment. I believe the Prime Minister must be praised for the readiness with which he will listen to voices within his own party and in the public telling him the damning facts about the uranium industry. Press innuendoes that Mr Hawke has backed off or backed down over the issue do no more than indicate the gutter mentality of some of the media and the attitude they take towards important public affairs. They seem to see the most important issues simply in terms of a horse race between intervals or as power struggles. These attitudes are wholly irresponsible and mischievous, and are widely perceived as such by the public.

Another issue on which the Government is not fronting up to the Australian people and on which it is not displaying the honesty mentioned in Senator Chaney 's matter of public importance is, of course, East Timor. I hope that those people in this and the other place who have urged that we quietly sell out the Timorese people have taken good note of recent statements by the Indonesian authorities in Timor that they now propose to wipe out their opponents by military means. This means that the brutal and bloody imposition of a quite unjustified and illegal act of conquest is to be continued by the simple means of killing more and more of the Timorese people-the classic final solution. Of course, the people must now die of their wounds or from torture without any help from the Red Cross. An article in the Melbourne Age reports that Portugal's President has expressed concern that the Indonesian military has refused to allow the Red Cross to provide urgently needed medical aid in East Timor. While I am on the issue of honesty in government I draw attention to reported comments by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, in an article in the Age in Melbourne on Wednesday, 19 October. The article states:
Mr Hayden described the report in yesterday's 'Age' as 'mischievous', ' provocative' and 'inaccurate' and claimed the reporter, Ian Davis, 'can be dangerous when he reports foreign affairs'.

On the very next day the statement I have mentioned from the President of Portugal came out. It is a thoroughly respectable situation. He said that the Indonesian people are refusing to allow the Red Cross to provide aid. One of the most disturbing aspects of this has been, first of all, Mr Hayden's comments which I think he should withdraw. Secondly, the Australian Government is apparently conniving at and actively supporting the Indonesian policy of destroying the Timorese people in secrecy. I refer to reports in the Age yesterday that the Australian Federal Police have been used to question a number of officials in the Department of Foreign Affairs about cables which were used by the Age on the East Timor issue earlier this week. I ask here and now whether this is an attempt by our Government to conceal vital facts about the issue and to seek to intimidate people of courage who may feel these facts should be known , as is right and proper, to the Australian people. I repeat that I believe that the comments made by Mr Hayden about Mr Ian Davis, which have been thoroughly justified by later reports, ought to occasion an apology to that journalist. What the public wants-this is coming through loud and clear to those who will listen-is a parliament made up of people who will not merely indulge in politicking, innuendo and back slanging as we have had in this Parliament today- -

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean the Democrats, don't you?

—Yes, indeed. I will tell the honourable senator what they are like. I was just about to get to that point, Senator Button. The public wants a parliament made up of people who will study the facts of the issues fearlessly and honestly and make decisions based on those facts and not on some weird, fuzzy and thoroughly old-fashioned ideological hangup of either the Labor or Liberal colour. That is really what people want. Quite a lot of elections are occurring in New South Wales and Queensland tomorrow. I certainly think that as a result of this debate a good many more people will vote Democrat. Indeed, in their own interests I urge them to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of Labor governments to keep their promises to the Australian people.

The Senate resumed at 2 o'clock this afternoon. Honourable senators will debate the matter of public importance for two hours until 4 o' clock. That is two hours of wasted time. The Senate sits on Friday to get through the legislative program of the Government. I am not denying the right of the Opposition to put this matter forward. I recognise that. It just seems to me an irresponsible waste of time to debate it at this time. All we have heard today is a whole lot of posturing and statements by the Opposition to try to set themselves up as judges and say that the Hawke Labor Government has not kept its promises when it has been in power for only eight months. It is like judging a person before he commits a crime just in case he commits it. The Hawke Labor Government has been in office for eight months and the Opposition has wasted two hours of the Senate's time. The debate will finish at 4 o'clock, the Senate will adjourn at 4.15 and hardly any work will have been carried out in the Senate today. I have just received a phone call from an ABC listener-I was quite surprised to hear from a person who had been listening to the ABC-who expressed his disgust at today's proceedings and the great waste of time perpetrated by the Opposition in raising this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said no one listens to Parliament?

—That is right. The Senate has been debating today the promises that the Australian Labor Party allegedly has not kept to this point. We ought to look at the discarded promises of the previous Government, the Fraser Government. If we were to do so we would find very clearly that hardly a promise made by the previous Prime Minister of this country was honoured. I think the result of the election showed that the people of Australia knew that he did not keep any of the promises he made to them. He made promises, those promises were broken, we went to an election, his Government was thrown out and an ALP government was elected. It is quite simple. I have before me a booklet of 37 foolscap pages-I do not intend to go through them all-of promises and broken promises by the previous Administration. If one were to adopt the Opposition's attitude and spend the time that it spent on this matter, one could read through the promises made and the promises broken by the previous Government. The previous Government's record is based on its being in government for a full term . This Government has been in power for only eight months.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast to the record of broken promises of the previous Government, one thing that can be said about the approach of the Hawke Labor Government is that it has been honest. The Government found when it came to power that the estimated Budget deficit had been lifted from $6 billion to $9.6 billion and that the money was not available to carry out some of the programs that it said it would carry out. But the Hawke Labor Government did not run away from the problem. It went to the people and explained what was happening in relation to its shortage of revenue and where it had to cut its program. It cut that program . The honesty of the Government and the way in which it has put propositions to the people were clearly shown in the results of the recent gallup poll which were published in the Advertiser in South Australia and in the Bulletin as one of the previous Labor speakers in this debate indicated. These polls were taken after eight months of the Hawke Labor Government. The article in the Advertiser stated:
Support for the Hawke Labor Government has stayed at a fairly constant high level since the Federal election in March, says the Gallup Poll.
The latest poll, taken on the first two weekends of this month, shows the Government with 52 p.c. of the total vote.
This is marginally above its level of support just before the August Budget, and is more than 2 p.c. up on its vote at the March Federal election.

If, as the Opposition has been saying today, the Labor Government has not been keeping its promises, and has been falling out of favour with the Australian electorate, why do the polls now show that the Federal Government, the Hawke Labor Government, is growing further in popularity throughout the Commonwealth of Australia? That is not the end of the story. We should not just look at the polls as they relate to the ALP Federal Government; we should look also at the figures in relation to the Liberal-National Party Government and the other parties. In the 1983 Federal election the Australian Labor party polled 49.5 per cent of the vote. In August-the time of the Budget-the Australian Labor Party would have received 51 per cent of the vote. The gallup poll shows that in October 1983 the vote of the Labor Party again reached 52 per cent. The vote of the Liberal-National Party Government at the time of the Federal election in March 1983 was shown to be 43.6 per cent. Today, in October 1983, the Liberal- National Party is shown as receiving 40 per cent of the vote. Its percentage vote has dropped 3.6 per cent since the last Federal election.

I turn to the second table. It gives the percentage of people who would support the Labor Party in an election and the percentage of people who would support the Liberal and National parties. Of men, 53 per cent support the Australian Labor Party. Thirty-eight per cent preferred the Liberal-National Party. Of women, 52 per cent would vote for the Labor Party and 41 per cent would vote for the Liberal and National parties. I could go on. I could go through each category of people aged between 18 and 24, 25 and 39, 40 and 54. Even in Tasmania, 55 per cent of people would support the Australian Labor Party and only 42 per cent the Liberal-National Party. If we were to have an election on the basis of promises not being kept, which is the basis of the attack by the Opposition, we would find that the Australian Labor Party would be returned to the Treasury benches with an increased majority.

When we talk about discarded promises and about the previous Administration-the Fraser Government-one has to look at the present Opposition and its defeat of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill put before the Senate two nights ago-on Wednesday night.

One can go from that point to look at what Prime Minister Hawke said in relation to that defeat in the Senate and what it means for the revenue to be received by the Labor Government. Very clearly, what members of the Opposition are saying today is being said tongue in cheek. They do not really mean what they are saying in relation to the Australian Labor Party. An article appearing in the Australian of 21 October 1983 states:

The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, yesterday warned of possible increases in personal taxes as a result of the Opposition defeat of amendments to the bottom- of-the-harbor legislation in the Senate on Wednesday.
The article continues:

The funds lost as a result of the action by this hypocritical Opposition are equivalent to a 1 per cent reduction in income tax on every Australian taxpayer. And for someone whose taxable income is equal to average weekly earnings, the loss would be $43 a year.
Further, the article states:
Apart from reducing revenue by $60 million in 1983-84, the defeat will mean the loss of $270 million in a full year.

That is what happened because of the action of the Opposition in relation to the Labor Government and the proposed legislation put before the Senate by the Hawke Labor Government. When we talk about governments and their broken promises, we ought to look at what is happening in Queensland. I believe that after the 22 October election there will be a Labor government in Queensland with Keith Wright as Premier. We ought to look at the record of the Government in Queensland. When we look at that record we should not take the view of the Government or a politician. Let us take an independent source. Let us look at a survey conducted in September 1983 by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Westpac Banking Corporation. I do not believe they are radical organisations. I do not believe that they would write a report that would suit just the Labor Party. I believe that for the first time in this debate, particularly when one considers the points raised by the Opposition, we can see some reasonable point of view being put forward which would at least give a clearer assessment of the situation in Queensland. It is stated:
The survey shows that Queensland is the only State in which the majority of businesses expected a decline in output.
And only 13 per cent of businesses in Queensland expected any improvement.
This is by far the lowest expectation of any mainland State and is much less than half of the national figure of 31 per cent.
Current business expectations with regard to unemployment in Queensland were far more pessimistic than in any other mainland State.
The same position applied to expectations of future employment in Queensland.

Queensland employers, according to the Westpac-Confederation of Australian Industry survey, are by far the most pessimistic of employers in the mainland States and much more pessimistic than in Australia as a whole. The survey conducted by Australian industry and the Westpac Banking Corporation clearly shows what is happening in Queensland and what has been happening to a situation which has now developed to the point shown in the survey. I think it is a clear indication that the Queensland Government will be defeated on 22 October. Today the Opposition has referred to broken promises. I will refer to what the Federal Government has done in relation to expenditure in my State of Queensland. If Queensland had a government which co-operated with the Federal Government we would find that expenditure of this money would certainly be put to greater benefit for the people of Queensland. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: — When I was interrupted this morning by Question Time I had looked at the basic spirit and purpose of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women and was about to look at its specific provisions. The first object of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 before the Senate is to 'give effect to certain provisions of the Convention'. An obligation of the Convention upon States-Australia is of course a ratifying party-is to adopt appropriate legislation and other measures including sanctions where appropriate prohibiting all discrimination against women. I wish specifically to look at provisions of the Convention because the fears that are being expressed about the Bill which I mentioned this morning, the types of fears concerning breakdown of the traditional family, are seen to have their root in the Convention. These people see the Bill and the Convention as a package and, of course, the two are integrated. What is the discrimination against women that the Convention seeks to outlaw? I quote from the Convention:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . discrimination against women'' shall mean any distinction, exclusion or restriction made on the basis of sex which has the effect or purpose of impairing or nullifying the recognition, enjoyment or exercise by women, irrespective of their marital status, on a basis of equality of men and women, of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the political, economic, social, cultural, civil or any other field.

That is Article 1 of the Convention. Again, it is very difficult for a reasonable person to criticise. So the dangers which have led these concerned persons to such dramatic conclusions must be found, I presume, more deeply within the document. I went in search of those dangers, but I did so recognising the broad and somewhat vague terms in which United Nations conventions are couched, and I was prepared to make the necessary allowances therefore.

Article 3 of the Convention obliges State parties to take all appropriate measures to ensure full development and advancement of women for the purposes of guaranteeing them the exercise and enjoyment of human rights and fundamental freedoms on the basis of equality with men. This has been condoned by some as in some way pressuring women to abandon the traditional role of home-maker. But really it appears a distorted interpretation. Rather, what it is is a statement that structural obstacles must not be allowed to limit women to no other choice. It is worth remembering that many a once-happy supported housewife has become a widow, deserted wife or divorcee and condemned to a future of low pay with little personal satisfaction and reward, because she, and her family for her, never envisaged a future for her other than as a traditional mother and home- maker. She had been stereotyped from a young age.

The other criticism, which is made particularly when Article 3 is read together with Article 4, is that the provision advocates affirmative action. I do not want to dwell upon affirmative action because, unlike the case with the previous Bill in 1981, the present Minister has decided to hasten slowly and has deleted such provisions from this Bill. Instead, we understand that she will issue a green paper for public discussion. However, as one of the arguments promoted against the Bill-and we heard it again this morning- is not what it contains but , rather, what it might lead to, I wish to make a few comments on affirmative action.

Affirmative action, as commonly envisaged, would require foreign financial and trading corporations to include in their management plans a strategy to eliminate discrimination against women in all sections of the particular company concerned. The argument for affirmative action was well explained in an article by Margaret Thornton which appeared in the Australian Quarterly of summer last year. She said:

Equal treatment assumes that the starting points for all are the same at the point of access, that is, in respect of job appointments, promotion and so on, and it ignores the history of past discrimination suffered by the stigmatised group. (The theory assumes that women applicants would be equally eligible as men for, say, an engineering position even though women are unlikely to apply, for it ignores the lengthy socialisation process which has militated against women pursuing the relevant educational and career path.) Equal treatment theory , then 'is sex blind'.

On the other hand, if we espouse the theory that equality of opportunity is directed towards equality of result, that is, the attainment of some ideal end- state, cognisance may be taken of unequal starting points. This theory permits affirmative action measures to be taken in favour of the disadvantaged group in order to make unequal starting points equal without offending the non- discrimination principle.

In other words, equality of result is, therefore, sex conscious. Equal treatment , which is as far as the Bill goes, is that the law is applied equally to those who are unequal. That is the principal argument of those advocating affirmative action. It is arguable that it will, therefore, not by itself achieve equality.
What sort of affirmative action might be taken? Professor Chipman, in a recent article in the Canberra Bulletin of Public Administration, lists:

such action as . . . counselling women who might have assumed they would not be seriously considered in application techniques, consciously seeking out promising women when seeking out promising junior staff for grooming for promotion, advertising posts using material which depicts women in positions of responsibility, reviewing the selection and promoting mechanisms to ensure that there are no unintended or hitherto unnoticed in-built biases towards men, and consulting with eligible women who do not apply for promotion to determine whether procedures are perceived, possibly inaccurately, to be sexist.

I must say that my reaction to such proposals is positive rather than negative. True, there would be a cost. However, in the longer term it may be that cost benefits would flow from being able to recruit talent from a pool which is doubled in size as a result of female participation. The matter, of course, becomes more contentious with reverse discrimination, which appears to be condoned by Article 4. Article 4 of the Convention states:

Adoption by states Parties of temporary special measures aimed at accelerating de facto equality between men and women shall not be considered discrimination as defined in the present Convention . . .

Reverse discrimination could be the permitting or requiring of discrimination in favour of women when qualified candidates for selection or promotion are other wise equal in merit; at a more extreme level, there could be reverse discrimination even if there are better qualified male applicants, provided that the woman appointed or promoted is adequately qualified. An even more extreme example is the giving of such advantage even though the best woman applicant is subqualified. The arguments that are advanced for reverse discrimination very briefly are these: First, the experience shows that other forms of affirmative action take a long time to work. Affirmative action, it is commonly said, does not achieve justice for women now. Secondly-and I see this as somewhat an obscure argument-an organisation which is addressed in its functions to women as well as men should be comparatively staffed. Thirdly, quite often one hears of the role model argument. Again, to quote Professor Chipman:

Girls, it is said, will be more likely to see certain careers as possible life paths for them if they see women occupying successful and responsible positions within those careers. Accelerated promotion with reverse discrimination if necessary may be justified on the utilitarian ground of inducing more young women to seek out such careers to which they would subsequently proceed without the need for reverse discrimination.

The arguments to the contrary include that what women are being offered is in effect tokenism; therefore it offers no real benefit to women, whilst at the same time it is costly to enterprise. What is better, it is argued by the opponents, is the approach of what one might call evolution-that is, through education, attitudes of parents can be changed; in schools girls will be educated to have the opportunity of choice; education of employers and of society generally will break down ingrained prejudices and stereotypes. I await the Green Paper with interest. I have read both praise and criticism of the American affirmative action progams. I have noted that the 1980 amendments to the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Act provide for moderate affirmative action. I think further debate on the subject will be worth while. To criticise this Bill on the basis of what might be a next step appears to me to be a very negative and not particularly constructive approach. Article 5 of the Convention provides:
States Parties shall take all appropriate measures:

(a) to modify the social and cultural patterns of conduct of men and women, with a view to achieving the elimination of prejudices and customary and all other practices which are based on the idea of the inferiority or the superiority of either of the sexes or on stereotyped roles for men and women . . .

The last few words-'stereotyped roles for men and women'-have caused concern because some fear this means pressure towards unisex. I invite the Senate rather to look to the mischief the clause is designed to overcome.

There is no doubt that girls have been stereotyped. As we heard from one honourable senator this morning, they are not stereotyped as motor mechanics, electrical engineers and so forth, but rather as secretaries, nurses and similar occupations. Traditionally, women were paid less. Now they are paid equally for the same work, but when stereotyped into occupations of 'women's work' paying less than occupations for men, 'men's work', room for valid criticism remains. To break down stereotyping is not to aim for unisex. It is allowing women equal right to have alternatives open to them.
Queen Margrethe II of Denmark put it clearly and succinctly when at the 1980 conference in Copenhagen, the World Conference on the United Nations Decade for Women, she said:

. . . to achieve equal rights and opportunities for men and women, we should always stress the personal capacity of the individual. We must become more flexible in our attitudes towards the role of men and women in society and avoid rigid concepts of stereotype roles for either sex.
Clause 5 (b) of the Convention provides that state parties should take all appropriate measures:

To ensure that family education includes a proper understanding of maternity as a social function and the recognition of the common responsibility of men and women in the upbringing and development of their children, it being understood that the interest of the children is the primordial consideration in all cases.

It has been put to me that it is terrible to talk about maternity as a social function. In some way that is supposed to be derogatory. But I believe it is time that we recognised mothering as a contribution to society to which a value attributes. Attempting to read the Convention within the spirit which underlies its existence, that appears to be the correct interpretation. Kurt Waldheim, the then Secretary-General of the United Nations, put it to the Copenhagen Conference in these terms:

Women are permanently at work but not permanently employed. They work long hours but are frequently not proportionately rewarded . . . Much of what they produce is not recognised in official statistics.

There is no doubt that in our industrialised society value tends to be assessed by payment. Therefore, unpaid domestic services tend to be subordinated. All this provision is saying is that it is time that the true worth of maternity was appreciated. The second part of clause 5 (b) promotes a common responsibility of both parents for the upbringing of children. It has been criticised as contrary to what is promoted as a traditional belief that women should have the primary responsibility for the upbringing of children. I am on record as not holding that view. Too often I have seen the corresponding secondary role of fathers become an abdication of responsibility. I therefore applaud any statement that both parents have the obligation for the upbringing of their children.

Regrettably, time will permit me to do no more than skim the balance of the Convention. Article 6 condemns all forms of traffic in women. Article 7 calls on states to eliminate discrimination in the political and public life of the country concerned. Article 8 calls for women to be given the opportunity to represent their governments at the international level. Article 9 calls upon states to grant women equal rights to men in relation to decisions determining their nationality and equal rights with respect to the nationality of their children. Articles 10, 11 and 12 call upon states to take all appropriate measures to eliminate discrimination against women in order to ensure them equal rights with men in the fields of education, employment and health care. Article 13 provides for a similar entitlement in other areas of economic and social life -the rights to family benefits, the same rights to finance and equal rights to participate in recreational activities.

Article 14 deals specifically with the particular problems of rural women. Article 15 calls for equality with men before the law. Article 16 states that women should have equality with men in marriage and family relations. The balance of the articles are administrative. I have concentrated on the Convention because, as I have indicated, much of the philosophical criticism of the Bill appears to relate to that Convention. But it appears to me to have been very much based on misinterpretation. I can find little in the Convention that is objectionable. On the contrary, it appears to be filled with ideals that are to be commended. As for the argument that it will destroy the traditional family , if anything, it appears to me to enhance the values on which strong families are based. There are lessons within the Convention which would strengthen some failing families.

The second major argument with which I wish to deal is that passing a law is not the way to overcome discrimination against women. A group of theologians expressed it in a paper forwarded to honourable senators in the following terms:
Yet the legislator is trying to bring about a society characterised by justice and law, but in doing so fails to understand the limited role of law in the education of attitudes and behaviour.

Clearly it is possible to overestimate the role of law in changing attitudes but it is also possible to underestimate that role. The Director of the Office of the Status of Women has argued the need for law in the following terms:
a law is an unequivocal declaration of public policy
a law gives support to those who do not wish to discriminate but who feel compelled to by social pressure
a law gives protection and redress for groups and individuals
a law provides for the peaceful and orderly adjustment of grievances and the release of tension
a law reduces discrimination by discouraging the behaviour in which discrimination finds expression
a law creates an awareness of individual rights and is a source of courage to those who wish to resist discrimination

I think that if equality of opportunity and access to goods and benefits is a desired social goal-I think all honourable senators would agree that it is-then the law can contribute to achieving that goal. I do not assert that law in itself is sufficient; many measures are needed. I would not downgrade the need for education programs, the need for adequate child care services to reduce the isolation of the home, the need for more flexible work arrangements and the need for better shared domestic responsibility. I have mentioned the need for tax reform and a more fair assessment of the value of certain jobs vis-a-vis others on other than a men's work-women's work basis. I do not even believe that law is necessary as a precondition for equality but it can make a more significant contribution.

The third and last question with which I wish to deal on this general subject of philosophy, the principles of the Bill, is the argument that the Bill is too radical, that the change is too dramatic and that society cannot adapt to changes at this pace. I think that that argument is quite astonishing. What does the Bill seek to do? Apart from giving effect to the Convention, which is really an overview and which reflects the spirit of the Bill, the Bill more specifically seeks the following:

to eliminate, so far as is possible, discrimination against persons on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the areas of work, accommodation, education, the provision of goods, facilities and services, the disposal of land , the activities of clubs and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs;
(c) to eliminate, so far as is possible, sexual harassment in the workplace and in educational institutions; and
(d) to promote recognition and acceptance within the community of the principle of the equality of men and women.

One would not think that that is particularly radical. Look at the history of this matter in Australia. There has been a National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation and six State committees since 1973. The purpose has been to implement the International Labour Organisation Convention III, a convention seeking to eliminate discrimination on grounds of race, colour, sex, religion, political opinion, national extraction and social origin in areas of employment and occupation. So it has been limited to employment and occupation and it has been hindered by not having legislative basis. But these committees have been in existence now for over a decade, basically to eliminate discrimination in the area of sex.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most people do not even know they exist.

—That is true, although I hope more know now. I remind the Senate that in South Australia there has been sex discrimination legislation since 1975 . It is worth mentioning that the first Bill was introduced in 1973 by Dr Tonkin , who later became the Liberal Premier of that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1983 (Hansard, page 526) Senator Elstob asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice concerning a recent report on national training and employment programs for young people. QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

The report referred to is Research Report No. 2 of the Bureau of Labour Market Research ('Employment and Training Programs for Young People: Analysis of Assistance in 1980-81') released on 31 July 1983. This report covered assistance provided during the 1980-81 financial year. The findings reflected the focus of labour force programs at that time on young people, consistent with the general concern in most Western industrialised countries about the high rates of unemployment sustained by young people. Since then, rates of unemployment for adult workers have increased substantially. The Government has moved rapidly to contain further increases by adopting policies designed to combat unemployment and inflation simultaneously, including in particular our prices and incomes policy.

We have also introduced the community employment program which aims to create in a full year up to 70,000 new jobs for unemployed people of all ages on worthwhile community projects of lasting value. To promote employment of long term unemployed adults in the private sector we have also provided substantially increased funds for the adult wage subsidy scheme. This scheme provides subsidies to employers taking on unemployed people over 25 who have been out of work for at least eight out of the last twelve months, additional payments in respect of those aged over 45 with more than 12 months continuous unemployment.
The Government will soon announce details of a review of all existing and work experience programs, which will include an appraisal of the labour market requirements of older job seekers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 September 1983 (Hansard, page 665) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the importation of botulinum toxin for the treatment of persons who have suffered head injuries resulting in their becoming cross-eyed.

QUESTION.PARA: As the Acting Minister for Health I now provide the following information:

An application to use botulinum toxin in a clinical trial for injection into the extra-ocular muscles of human patients to alter alignment of the eyes was received by the Department of Health from an individual medical practitioner during 1982. Only limited data were presented and the applicant was advised of the departmental requirements for the submission of data to support such an application. No further correspondence has been received on the matter and until such time as the necessary data have been provided and evaluated no approval may be given for the importation of this very potent toxin into Australia.

The information currently available to the Department suggests that the use of botulinum toxin for the proposed purpose has not yet been proven and it is still only in investigational status. Further consideration would be given to the application to conduct a clinical trial in Australia should the necessary data be provided.
